Title: Linux Kernel routing_ioctl() Bug May Let Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux Kernel.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can issue a large number of fget() calls such that a reference counter will overrun and a subsequent fput() call will cause the wrong resources to be freed.  As a result, the kernel may crash.

64-bit Symmetric Multi-Processor (SMP) systems may be affected.

Vasiliy Averin discovered this vulnerability.

The 32-bit tiocgdev ioctl() function on x86-64 systems contains the same type of vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause the kernel to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (2.6.13.2), available at:

http://kernel.org/

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Buffer Overflows in Moxa Char Driver Yield Root Privileges to Local Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Some buffer overflow vulnerabilities were reorted in the Linux kernel in the moxa char driver.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
The driver does not properly validate the length of certain user-supplied inputs.

The flaws reside in 'drivers/char/moxa.c' in the MoxaDriverIoctl(), moxaloadbios(), moxaloadcode(), and moxaload320b() functions.

This vulnerability was reported in January 2005 by Brad Spengler of grsecurity.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution:
Red Hat has released a fix.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Race Condition  in ia32 Compatability Code Yields Root Privileges to Local Users
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A race condition vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the ia32 compatibility code.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel level privileges.
The ia32 compatibility execve() system call contains a race condition, affecting x86_64 and ia64 architectures.

A local user can invoke the get_user() function to block while a blocking kmalloc() call is made in the sys32_execve() function.  As a result, the local user's thread can modify pointers processed by the sys32_execve() function to trigger a buffer overflow.

A local user may be able to cause a kernel panic or execute arbitrary code with kernel ring 0 privileges.

Ilja van Sprundel from Suresec discovered this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.suresec.org/advisories/adv4.pdf
Impact':
A local user can cause the kernel to crash.

A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel level privileges.
Solution:
Red Hat has released a fix.

Title: Linux Kernel Memory Leak in syscall32_setup_pages() May Let Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel.  A local user can trigger a memory leak.
The syscall32_setup_pages() function in 'syscall32.c' does not check the return value of the insert_vm_struct() function.  A local user can create a 32-bit application with a specially crafted ELF header that, when executed, will cause the system to fail to free allocated memory.

A local user may be able to exploit this to cause denial of service conditions.
Impact': A local user can cause a memory leak, which may result in denial of service conditions.
Solution:
A source code fix is available at:

http://www.kernel.org/git/?p=linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux-2.6.git;a=commitdiff;h=9fb1759a3102c26cd8f64254a7c3e532782c2bb8

Title: Linux Kernel ptrace find_target() Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
In January 2005, a vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in 'ptrace32.c'.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can execute 'ltrace -i' using the 32-bit version of ltrace on a 64-bit executable to cause the kernel to crash.

This find_target() function does not properly handle a NULL value returned from find_task_by_pid() in this case.  As a result, the put_task_struct() is called and a kernel oops may occur.

Mark Bellon reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause the kernel to crash.
Solution:
A source code fix is available.  The BitKeeper change set is available at:

http://linux.bkbits.net:8080/linux-2.4/cset@41dd3455GwQPufrGvBJjcUOXQa3WXA

A fix may also be available in 2.4.29.

Red Hat has issued a fix for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 3:

https://rhn.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2005-663.html

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux Kernel binfmt_elf Loader Lets Local Users Obtain Root Access
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Some vulnerabilities were reported in the Linux kernel in the binfmt_elf loader.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.

A local user can exploit these flaws to cause a setuid binary to execute arbitrary code.

The original advisory, including some demonstration exploit code, is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0017-binfmt_elf.txt
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with setuid privileges to obtain root access on the target system.
Solution:
Red Hat has released a fix.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux Kernel binfmt_elf Loader Lets Local Users Obtain Root Access
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Some vulnerabilities were reported in the Linux kernel in the binfmt_elf loader.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the target system.
Paul Starzetz reported several flaws in the ELF loader in the processing of set user id (setuid) binaries.  These flaws include incorrect return value validation in the load_elf_binary() function, some faulty error handling, and an unterminated string bug in 'binfmt_elf.c' and also a file-type validation bug in 'exec.c' that allows non-readable ELF binaries to be read.

A local user can exploit these flaws to cause a setuid binary to execute arbitrary code.

The original advisory, including some demonstration exploit code, is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0017-binfmt_elf.txt
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with setuid privileges to obtain root access on the target system.
Solution:
Red Hat has issued a fix.

Title: Linux Kernel pktcdvd and rawdevice Errors Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the pktcdvd and rawdevice ioctl handlers.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel level privileges.
The Linux rawdevice and pktcdvd block device ioctl handlers do not properly validate certain user-supplied parameters.  A local user can supply a specially crafted parameter value to break the user space limit and rewrite kernel data, causing arbitrary code to be executed with kernel privileges.

The vulnerability resides in 'drivers/block/pktcdvd.c'.

alert7 discovered this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel level privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Linux Kernel sysfs File Permissions Set By it87 and via686a Drivers Allow Local Users to Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the it87 and via686a drivers.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
The it87 and via686a hardware monitoring drivers create a sysfs file named 'alarms' in read/write mode instead of read-only mode. As a result, a local user can attempt to write to the file to cause denial of service conditions on the target system.  For example, this may cause CPU utilization to reach 100%.
Impact': A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (2.6.11.8), available at:

http://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/kernel/v2.6/

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux bluez_sock_create() Integer Underflow Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the Bluetooth socket code.  A local user can gain root privileges.
The vulnerability resides in the bluez_sock_create() function.  A local user can supply a negative integer value to the function to cause incorrect memory access.  The kernel may then execute user-supplied code.

Ilja van Sprundel discovered this vulnerability.  Suresec Ltd reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution:
Red Hat has released a fix.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux ext2_make_empty() Discloses Information to Remote and Local Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel ext2 implementation.  A remote or local user can view potentially sensitive kernel memory contents.
The ext2_make_empty() function does not properly clear filesystem contents when creating a directory.  The block written to store the '.' and '..' directory entries is not properly initialized.  As a result, approximately 4k of kernel memory may be leaked into the file system for each directory created.

A local or remote user with access to the filesystem (or filesystem images or devices) can obtain potentially sensitive information.

The vendor was notified on March 16, 2005.

The original advisory is available at:

http://arkoon.net/advisories/ext2-make-empty-leak.txt

Mathieu Lafon and Romain Francoise from Arkoon Security Team reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A user with access to the filesystem (or filesystem images or devices) can view portions of kernel memory.
Solution:
Red Hat has released a fix.

Title: Linux ext2_make_empty() Discloses Information to Remote and Local Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel ext2 implementation.  A remote or local user can view potentially sensitive kernel memory contents.
The ext2_make_empty() function does not properly clear filesystem contents when creating a directory.  The block written to store the '.' and '..' directory entries is not properly initialized.  As a result, approximately 4k of kernel memory may be leaked into the file system for each directory created.

A local or remote user with access to the filesystem (or filesystem images or devices) can obtain potentially sensitive information.

The vendor was notified on March 16, 2005.

The original advisory is available at:

http://arkoon.net/advisories/ext2-make-empty-leak.txt

Mathieu Lafon and Romain Francoise from Arkoon Security Team reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A user with access to the filesystem (or filesystem images or devices) can view portions of kernel memory.
Solution:
The vendor has issued fixed versions (2.4.30-rc2, 2.6.11.6), available at:

http://kernel.org/

Title: Linux Kernel Deadlock Error in futex Functions Let Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the LInux kernel futex functions.  A local user can cause the kernel to crash.
Some kernel futex functions invoke get_user() calls while holding mmap_sem for reading.  If a get_user() function fails while another thread is in mmap, then the do_page_fault() function will deadlock.

Another similar deadlock condition may occur.

A local user can exploit this to cause denial of service conditions on the target system.

The flaw resides in 'kernel/futex.c'.

Olof Johansson reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause the target system to crash.
Solution:
A development patch (and changeset) is available, as described at:

http://lkml.org/lkml/2005/2/22/185

Title: Linux Kernel Bug in load_elf_library Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel ELF loader.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
A local user can invoke the load_elf_library to modify 'elf_phdata', causing the wrong memory to be freed.

The flaw resides in '/fs/binfmt_elf.c'.

Yichen Xie discovered this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can cause the kernel to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (2.4.30-rc2, 2.6.11.6), available at:

http://kernel.org/

Title: Linux bluez_sock_create() Integer Underflow Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the Bluetooth socket code.  A local user can gain root privileges.
The vulnerability resides in the bluez_sock_create() function.  A local user can supply a negative integer value to the function to cause incorrect memory access.  The kernel may then execute user-supplied code.

Ilja van Sprundel discovered this vulnerability.  Suresec Ltd reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution: A fix is available in 2.6.11.6 and 2.4.30-rc3.

Title: Linux PPP Driver Lets Remote Users Crash the System
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel ppp driver.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can send a specially crafted ppp packet to cause the target system to hang.

The flaw resides in 'drivers/net/ppp_async.c'.

Ben Martel and Stephen Blackheath discovered this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target system to hang.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a kernel fix (2.6.11.4), available at:

http://kernel.org/

Title: Linux Kernel Buffer Overflows in Moxa Char Driver Yield Root Privileges to Local Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Some buffer overflow vulnerabilities were reported in the Linux kernel in the moxa char driver.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
The driver does not properly validate the length of certain user-supplied inputs.

The flaws reside in 'drivers/char/moxa.c' in the MoxaDriverIoctl(), moxaloadbios(), moxaloadcode(), and moxaload320b() functions.

This vulnerability was reported in January 2005 by Brad Spengler of grsecurity.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution:
Some unofficial patches are available in the original report at:

http://lists.netsys.com/pipermail/full-disclosure/2005-January/030660.html

Title: Linux Kernel '/proc' Signed Integer Errors Let Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in '/proc'.  A local user can execute arbitrary code or view kernel memory to gain elevated privileges.
The kernel does not properly manage signed integer types in certain cases.  A local user can trigger a buffer overflow or view kernel memory.

Some flaws reside in the proc_file_read() function in 'fs/proc/generic.c', where a call to min_t() uses an incorrect integer definition, and in the locks_read_proc() function where an integer parameter is incorrectly defined.  A local user can trigger a buffer overflow.

A vulnerability in 'drivers/char/n_tty.c' lets local users view kernel memory.

A potential integer mismatch vulnerability exists in 'net/atm/resources.c' and 'net/atm/addr.c' and also in the reiserfs_copy_from_user_to_file_region() function in 'fs/reiserfs/file.c'.

Georgi Guninski reported these vulnerabilities.

The original advisory (including demonstration exploit code) is available at:

http://www.guninski.com/where_do_you_want_billg_to_go_today_3.html
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code on the target system or view kernel memory.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (2.6.11-rc4), availabe at:

http://www.kernel.org/

Patches are also available at:

http://linux.bkbits.net:8080/linux-2.6/cset@4201818eC6aMn0x3GY_9rw3ueb2ZWQ?nav=index.html|ChangeSet@-4w
http://linux.bkbits.net:8080/linux-2.6/cset@420181322LZmhPTewcCOLkubGwOL3w?nav=index.html|ChangeSet@-4w
http://linux.bkbits.net:8080/linux-2.6/cset@4208e1fcfccuD-eH2OGM5mBhihmQ3A?nav=index.html|ChangeSet@-4w
http://linux.bkbits.net:8080/linux-2.6/cset@42018227TkNpHlX6BefnItV_GqMmzQ?nav=index.html|ChangeSet@-4w

Title: Linux Kernel NTFS File System Error Messages May Let Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the processing of NTFS file system errors.  A user may be able to cause denial of service conditions.
The vendor reported that the NTFS file system support in the Linux kernel does not properly limit kernel error messages.  A user may be able to cause the ntfs_warning() and ntfs_error() functions to generate an excessive amount of log messages, resulting in potential denial of service conditions.

The flaw resides in 'fs/ntfs/debug.c'.

Carl-Daniel Hailfinger from SuSE is credited with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A user may be able to cause denial of service conditions.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (2.6.11-rc3), available at:

http://www.kernel.org/

Title: Linux Kernel coda_pioctl Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
In December 2004, a vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the coda_pioctl function.  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.
Bryan Fulton reported that a source code checker by Coverity detected a flaw in the coda functionality in 'pioctl.c'.  A local user can supply negative vi.in_size or vi.out_size values to the coda_pioctl() function to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code.
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.
Solution:
Fixes are available at:

http://linux.bkbits.net:8080/linux-2.6/cset@41e40c4cXMJpzlmvtt48jmdmdi7_Gw
http://linux.bkbits.net:8080/linux-2.4/cset@41e2bcc80m08xKvcOTyeN4AAerqKdA

Title: Linux Kernel Overlapping VMAs May Let Local Users Obtain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the procesing of ELF binaries on IA64 systems.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions or potentially obtain root privileges on the target system.
The vendor reported that a local user can create a specially crafted binary that, when run on the target system, will cause the system to crash.  The flaw occurs because the system does not properly check for overlapping virtual memory address allocations.

This bug is similar to that reported in Alert ID 1012165 [CVE: CVE-2004-1074], where a local user can obtain root level privileges.
Impact':
A local user can cause the target system to crash.

A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with setuid privileges to obtain root access on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a patch for 2.6, available at:

http://linux.bkbits.net:8080/linux-2.6/cset@41a6721cce-LoPqkzKXudYby_3TUmg

Title: Linux Kernel Multiprocessor Page Fault Handler Race Condition Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the page fault handler code for multiprocessor systems.  A local user can obtain root privileges.
Paul Starzetz of iSEC Security Research reported that if two concurrent threads share the same virtual memory space and request stack expansion at the same time, a race condition can be exploited on multiprocessor systems.  A local user can cause arbitrary memory contents to be injected into memory locations used by a set user id (setuid) application to execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.

The flaw resides in the down_read() function in 'arch/i386/mm/fault.c'.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0022-pagefault.txt
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges.
Solution:
No upstream solution was available at the time of this entry.

The report indicates that Red Hat issued a fix as part of kernel-2.4.21-27.EL.

Title: Linux Kernel uselib() Race Condition Lets Local Users Obtain Root Level Privileges
Version(s): 2.4 up to and including 2.4.29-rc2, 2.6 up to and including 2.6.10
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the uselib() functions.  A local user can obtain root privileges.
Paul Starzetz of iSEC Security Research reported that the Linux binary format loader load_elf_library() function in 'binfmt_elf.c' does not properly process memory segments.  A do_brk() call is made without holding the relevant mmap semaphore.  As a result, a local user can exploit a race condition to inject a virtual memory address descriptor into the wrong location and cause arbitrary code to be executed with root privileges.

The binfmt_aout binary format loader contains a similar flaw.

The original advisory is available at:

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) Linux Kernel do_fork() Memory Allocation Flaw Lets Local Users Consume Memory Resources and Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the do_fork() function.  A local user may be able to cause denial of service conditions.
John Byrne reported that a local user can trigger an error in do_fork() after the mm_struct for the child has been allocated and the mm_count counter has been incremented such that the counter will not be decremented and the allocated memory will not be freed.

In the 'CLONE_VM' case, a similar error condition may occur, where the parent's mm_struct will have the mm_count incremented and never decremented.
Impact': A local user may be able to cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
Conectiva has released a fix.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Buffer Overflow in ISO9660 File System Rock Ridge Extension Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
iDEFENSE reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in the Linux kernel in the ISO9660 file system.  A local user can gain kernel level access on the system in certain cases.
It is reported that the kernel does not validate the length of symbolic links (symlinks) on ISO9660 file systems.

A local user can create and mount a CD that contains specially crafted symlinks to trigger the overflow in the kernel and execute arbitrary code.

The flaw can be triggered by performing a file or directory access on a specially crafted ISO9660 file system (such as a directory listing of file access), the report said.

The vulnerability reportedly resides in the support for the 'Rock Ridge' extension to the ISO9660 file system ('fs/isofs/rock.c') in the rock_ridge_symlink_readpage() and get_symlink_chunk() functions.

The vendor was reportedly notified on February 20, 2004.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel level privileges.
Solution:
Conectiva has released a fix.

Title: Linux Kernel Auxiliary Message Layer State Error Lets Local Users Deny Service
Version(s): 2.4 up to and including 2.4.28, 2.6 up to and including 2.6.9
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the auxiliary message (scm) layer.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
Paul Starzetz of iSEC Security Research reported that a local user can send a specially crafted auxiliary message to a socket to trigger a deadlock condition in the __scm_send() function.

Title: Linux Kernel IGMP Integer Underflow Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): 2.4 up to and including 2.4.28, 2.6 up to and including 2.6.9
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the Linux kernel in the processing of IGMP messages.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privleges.  A remote user can cause the target system to crash.
Paul Starzetz of iSEC Security Research reported that there is a flaw in the ip_mc_source() function, where a local user can invoke the IGMP API to cause the 'sl_count' signed integer counter to be decremented to a negative number.  As a result, the kernel will hang for a temporary period of time (approximately several minutes, depending on the system) and then will modify kernel memory.  A local user can exploit this to cause the system to crash or to gain elevated privileges.  A local user can also exploit this to read large portions of kernel memory.

It is also reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted IGMP group query to trigger a kernel memory read access error in the igmp_marksources() function.  If the system has been compiled with multicasting support and if an application on the system has opened a multicast socket, then the system may be vulnerable.  A remote user can cause the system to crash.

A demonstration exploit for the local denial of service vulnerability is included in the original advisory, available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0018-igmp.txt
Impact':
A local user can cause the target system to crash.

A local user may be able to gain elevated privleges.

A remote user can cause the target system to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (SuSE Issues Fix) Linux Kernel smbfs Filesystem Memory Errors Let Remote Users Crash the System
Version(s): 8.1, 8.2, 9.0, 9.1, 9.2, SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 8, 9, SUSE LINUX Desktop 1.0, Novell Linux Desktop 9
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the Linux kernel in the smbfs filesystem.  A remote user can cause the target system to crash.
Stefan Esser of e-matters GmbH reported that a remote user with control of a smb server (or the ability to conduct a man-in-the-middle attack) can cause the connected smb server to supply specially crafted replies to the target system to exploit these flaws.  A remote user can cause kernel memory leaks and cause the kernel to crash.

It is reported that the kernel does not properly validate some data received from the connected smb server [CVE: CVE-2004-0883].

In the 2.4 kernel, specially crafted data can trigger an overflow in smb_proc_read(), an offset error in smb_proc_readX(), and a defragmentation overflow in smb_receive_trans2().  Denial of service conditions may occur.

In the 2.6 kernel, an offset boundary error in smb_proc_readX_data() permits denial of service attacks.

In both 2.4 and 2.6 kernels, memory errors can be triggered in smb_receive_trans2() to cause denial of service or a kernel memory leak.

It is also reported that a memory initialization error and a counter error in smb_recv_trans2() may leak kernel memory [CVE: CVE-2004-0949].  The 2.4 and 2.6 kernels are affected.

The vendor was notified on September 25, 2004.

The original advisory is available at:

http://security.e-matters.de/advisories/142004.html
Impact':
A remote user may be able to view portions of kernel memory.

A remote user can cause the kernel to crash.
Solution:
SUSE has released a fix.  See the SUSE advisory for specific kernel installation instructions:

http://www.novell.com/linux/security/advisories/2004_42_kernel.html

Title: (SuSE Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Privileged Instruction Error May Let Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel.  A local user may be able to gain root privileges.
A local user can invoke an unspecified privileged instruction to trigger a flaw in processing that instruction that may allow the local user to obtain root privileges.

Martin Schwidefsky of IBM is credited with discovering this flaw.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain root privileges.
Solution: SuSE has released a fix.  Of SuSE's products, only the SuSE Linux Enterprise Server 9 on the S/390 platform is affected by this flaw.

Title: Linux Kernel TIOCSETLD tty Race Condition May Disclose Kernel Memory or Cause the System to Crash
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the tty code.  A remote authenticated user may be able to cause the system to crash.  A local user may be able to view small portions of kernel memory.
Red Hat reported that there are tty security issues in the Linux 2.6 kernel.

Alan Cox later provided additional details, also indicating that the 2.2 and 2.4 kernels are affected.

It is reported that a local user can issue a TIOCSETLD ioctl on a terminal interface while another thread is performing read or write operations to potentially gain access to small amounts of random kernel memory or cause the system to crash.

A remote authenticated user can also connect to a PPP dial-up port and issue a switch from console to ppp and then send data at the appropriate time so that the data arrives during the line discipline switch to cause the system to crash.

It is reported that these conditions are exploitable over a raw serial link but may not be exploitable over a modem becuase the modem adds sufficient randomization to make it difficult to send data at the appropriate time.
Impact':
A remote authenticated user can cause the system to crash.

A local user can view small, random portions of kernel memory.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix in the prepatch 2.6.9rc4, available at:

http://kernel.org/pub/linux/kernel/v2.6/testing/patch-2.6.9-rc4.bz2

A fix is also available in 2.6.9.

Patches are also available for the 2.4 kernel.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) Linux Kernel sys_chown() Bug May Let Remote NFS Users Modify Group Permissions on Files
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel.  A remote authenticated user can modify the group permissions of files on the target system.
It is reported that users can modify the group ID of arbitrary files on the system due to a missing check for fsuid in the sys_chown() function.  An NFS client may be able to  make unauthorized changes to the group ownership of files on a remote system.
Impact': A remote authenticated user can modify the group permissions of arbitrary files on the target system.
Solution:
Conectiva has released a fix.

Title: Linux Kernel ide-cd SG_IO Flaw May Let Local Users Write to Media
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel SG_IO functions in ide-cd.  A local user may be able to perform unauthorized write and erase operations.
It is reported that a local user with read-only access to an ide-cd device may be able to issue arbitrary commands, such as 'write' or 'erase firmware'.

A discussion of the vulnerability is available at:

http://lkml.org/lkml/2004/7/31/84
Impact': A local user may be able to performed unauthorized write operations on the target media.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Linux Kernel TCP Socket State Error Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the processing of TCP sockets.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
Dale Corse reported that a local user can cause a socket to be reused before it is closed by the previous caller.  As a result, the local user can cause sockets to remain in the TIME_WAIT state until expiration and in the CLOSE_WAIT for an indefinite period of time.  This can be exploited to consume all available sockets.

David S. Miller indicates that this may not be a vulnerability.
Impact': A local user can consume all available sockets, denying service to network-based applications on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (SuSE Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Integer Overflow in kNFSd Lets Remote Users Panic the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Version(s): 8.1, 8.2, 9.0, 9.1, SUSE Linux Database Server, SUSE eMail Server III, 3.1, SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 8, 9, SUSE Linux Connectivity Server, SUSE Linux Office Server
Description:
An integer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in kNFSd.  A remote user can cause the target system to crash.
SuSE reported that there are various "signedness issues and integer overflows" in the kNFSd and the XDR decode functions in the Linux 2.6 kernel.  A remote user can send a packet with a trusted source address that contains a write request with a size that is greater then 2^31 to cause a kernel panic.

It is not know whether this bug can cause arbitrary code execution.

The 2.4 kernel may also be affected.

It is also reported that a local user can cause denial of service conditions via /dev/ptmx on a Linux 2.6 kernel.  Jan Engelhardt is credited with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can cause a kernel panic.
Solution:
SuSE has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: Linux Kernel USB Driver Uninitialized Structures May Disclose Kernel Memory to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in certain USB drivers.  A local user may be able to obtain kernel memory contents.
Several vendors reported that certain USB drivers in the Linux kernel use uninitialized structures and then make copy_to_user(...) kernel calls from these structures.  As a result, a local user may be able to obtain uninitialized kernel memory contents.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain portions of kernel memory.
Solution:
A fixed kernel version (2.4.27) is available at:

http://kernel.org/

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Linux Kernel 64-bit to 32-bit File Offset Conversion Errors Disclose Kernel Memory to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the processing of 64-bit file offset pointers.  A local user can view kernel memory.
Paul Starzetz reported that the kernel's file handling API does not properly convert 64-bit file offsets to 32-bit file offsets. In addition, the kernel provides insecure access to the file offset member variable.  As a result, a local user can gain read access to large portions of kernel memory.

It is reported that most of the /proc entries (such as /proc/version) leak approximately one page of unitialized kernel memory.

Improper conversions were identified in dozens of places within the code.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0016-procleaks.txt
Impact': A local user can read large portions of kernel memory.
Solution:
Mandrake has released a fix.

Impact': A local user can read large portions of kernel memory.
Solution: Individual Linux kernel distribution vendors will be releasing fixes for their distributions.

Title: Linux Kernel 'eql.c' Device Driver Error Lets Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the equalizer load-balancer for serial network interfaces.  A local user can cause the system to crash.
Vitaly Bursov reported that a local user can invoke either the eql_g_slave_cfg() function or the eql_s_slave_cfg() function and supply a non-existent slave device name to cause the kernel to crash.

The flaw resides in 'drivers/net/eql.c'.
Impact': A local user can cause the system to crash.
Solution:
A source code patch is available at:

http://linux.bkbits.net:8080/linux-2.6/cset@40d4aa72hPLWy-jMLr0eJAXMxHcNZg

Title: Linux IA64 Floating Point Register Access Control Error May Disclose Information to Local Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel on ia64-based systems.  A local user may be able to view sensitive information from another process.
Arun Sharma reported on Red Hat's bugzilla that the context switch code only checks the psr.mfh bit and does not check the FPH ownership. As a result, a local user can set the MFH bit and then examine the registers that may contain data from another process.

The original bug report is available at:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=124734
Impact': A local user may be able to view registers containing data set by another process.
Solution:
A patch is available at:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla/attachment.cgi?id=100687&action=view

Title: Linux Netfilter tcp_find_option Infinite Loop Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Linux netfilter.  A remote user can cause the target system's network interfaces to become unavailable.
Adam Osuchowski reported that there is a signed integer error in netfilter, affecting Linux 2.6 kernels.  The error only occurs when using iptables with rules matching TCP options (i.e.,  --tcp-option), the report said.

The flaw reportedly resides in 'net/ipv4/netfilter/ip_tables.c' in the tcp_find_option() function.

A remote user can reportedly send a specially crafted TCP packet with the TCP options length value greater than 127 to cause the system to enter an infinite loop.

A demonstration exploit packet is provided:

0x0000:  4500 0030 1234 4000 ff06 e83f c0a8 0001
0x0010:  c0a8 0002 0400 1000 0000 0064 0000 0064
0x0020:  7000 0fa0 dc6a 0000 0204 05b4 0101 04fd

Adam Osuchowski also credits Tomasz Dubinski with jointly discovering and repairing the vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause the system's network interfaces to become unavailable.

Title: Linux Kernel SBus PROM Driver Integer Overflows Let Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
Several integer overflow vulnerabilities were reported in the Linux kernel in the SBus PROM driver.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.
Sean reported that a local user can supply specially crafted values to overflow some integer variables, causing buffers to be allocated that are too small to copy the amount of user-supplied data.

The report indicated that the source of the driver is generally located at:

/usr/src/linux/drivers/sbus/char/openprom.c

The flaws reportedly reside in the copyin() and copyin_string() functions.

The report states that it may be possible to execute arbitrary code, but that was not confirmed.

The vendor was reportedly notified.
Impact': A local user can cause the system to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix for RHEL) Linux Kernel Flaws in Several Drivers May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
Some unspecified vulnerabilities were reported in the Linux kernel in several drivers.  A local user can gain access to kernel memory or gain elevated privileges on the target system.
Red Hat and Trustix reported that during a review of the Linux 2.6 source code, some vulnerabilities were discovered.  Some of the flaws are also reported to apply to the 2.4 kernel.

The aironet, asus_acpi, decnet, mpu401, msnd, and pss drivers are reportedly affected.
Impact':
A local user may be able to gain access to kernel memory.

A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Red Hat has released a fix.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix for RHEL) Linux Kernel do_fork() Memory Allocation Flaw Lets Local Users Consume Memory Resources and Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the do_fork() function.  A local user may be able to cause denial of service conditions.
John Byrne reported that a local user can trigger an error in do_fork() after the mm_struct for the child has been allocated and the mm_count counter has been incremented such that the counter will not be decremented and the allocated memory will not be freed.

In the 'CLONE_VM' case, a similar error condition may occur, where the parent's mm_struct will have the mm_count incremented and never decremented.
Impact': A local user may be able to cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
Red Hat has released a fix.

Title: Linux Kernel Flaws in Several Drivers May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
Some unspecified vulnerabilities were reported in the Linux kernel in several drivers.  A local user can gain access to kernel memory or gain elevated privileges on the target system.
Red Hat and Trustix reported that during a review of the Linux 2.6 source code, some vulnerabilities were discovered.  Some of the flaws are also reported to apply to the 2.4 kernel.

The aironet, asus_acpi, decnet, mpu401, msnd, and pss drivers are reportedly affected.
Impact':
A local user may be able to gain access to kernel memory.

A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution: Individual kernel vendors are issuing fixes.

Title: (SuSE Issues Fix) Linux Kernel FPU Processing Error Lets Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system

Title: Linux Kernel Integer Overflow in i2c Driver Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
An integer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the i2c driver.  A local user can crash the kernel or gain kernel-level privilges.
Shaun Colley reported that the vulnerability resides in 'i2c-core.c' in the i2cproc_bus_read() function, where the user-supplied 'count' variable is not properly validated.  A local user can supply a negative value for 'count' to trigger the flaw and cause the kernel to crash or potentially execute arbitrary code.

Only kernels that include the i2c driver are affected, the report said.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel-level privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix) Linux Kernel do_mremap() Fails to Check do_munmap() Return Values, Allowing a Local User to Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Another vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Paul Starzetz discovered and reported that there is a missing return value check within the mremap(2) system call.

When resizing or moving virtual memory areas, the function reportedly does not test the return value of the do_munmap() function.  Cases where the function fails (for example, due to the number of virtual memory areas being exceeded by the calling process) will not be properly detected, according to the report.  As a result, the kernel may move memory belonging to one process into memory space that is allocated to another process.

Some other calls to the do_munmap() function are also not checked, the report said.

A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0014-mremap-unmap.txt
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix.

Title: Linux Kernel e1000 Initialization Error May Disclose Kernel Memory to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the e1000 Ethernet card driver.  A local user may be able to view portions of kernel memory.
Ken Ashcraft reported (http://www.uwsg.iu.edu/hypermail/linux/kernel/0404.2/0139.html) that the 'e1000_ethtool.c' contains a flaw where unbounded input is used in a copy_to_user() function call.
Impact': A local user may be able to view portions of kernel memory.
Solution: A fix is available in version 2.4.27-pre1.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Linux Kernel cpufreq Signed Integer Assignment Flaw Discloses Memory to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the cpufreq_userspace proc handler.  A local user may be able to read kernel memory.
Red Hat reported that the Linux kernel contains a signed integer boundary error in the cpufreq ioctl proc handler.  A user-supplied signed integer is cast to a signed integer and then used in copying memory.  As a result, a local user can read or write arbitrary amounts of kernel memory.

A local user can read arbitrary portions of kernel memory.  A root-level user can also write to arbitrary memory locations.

The flaw resides in 'drivers/cpufreq/cpufreq_userspace.c'.

Brad Spengler is credited with discovering this flaw.
Impact': A local user can read arbitrary portions of kernel memory.
Solution:
Mandrake has released a fix.

Title: (Trustix Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Integer Overflow in sctp_setsockopt() Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code With Kernel Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): Trustix Secure Linux 2.0, 2.1; Trustix Secure Enterprise Linux 2
Description:
An integer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel in the SCTP sctp_setsockopt() function.  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the target system with kernel-level privileges.  [Editor's note:  This report has been disputed.]
Shaun Colley reported that a local user can trigger an integer overflow in the sctp_setsockopt() option when the 'SCTP_SOCKOPT_DEBUG_NAME' socket option is set.  The flaw reportedly resides in 'net/sctp/socket.c', where an unsigned integer (optlen) that governs memory allocation may be incremented even when the integer is at its maximum value.  As a result, a remote user can supply a value such that the integer will overflow and the function will not allocate enough memory to hold the user-supplied 'optval' contents.  A subsequent copy_from_user() function call will then copy large amounts of user-supplied data to kernel memory, overwriting portions of kernel memory.

Stefan Esser reported that sys_setsockopt() first checks to ensure that optlen is not less than zero, so an integer overflow cannot occur.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges.
Solution:
Trustix has released a fix, available at:

http://http.trustix.org/pub/trustix/updates/
ftp://ftp.trustix.org/pub/trustix/updates/

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix for RH Enterprise Linux) Linux 2.4 Kernel /proc/tty/driver/serial May Disclose Password Characteristics to Local Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A flaw in '/proc/tty/driver/serial' may let local users gain information about password characteristics.
It is reported that '/proc/tty/driver/serial discloses the exact character counts for information on the serial links.  A local user can monitor this object to attempt to determine the length of a target user's password (as typed) and keystroke timing, which can yield information about the target user's password.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain information about password lengths and password keystroke timing.
Solution:
Red Hat has released a fix.

Title: Linux Kernel Integer Overflow in sctp_setsockopt() Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code With Kernel Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
An integer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel in the SCTP sctp_setsockopt() function.  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the target system with kernel-level privileges.  [Editor's note:  This report has been disputed.]
Shaun Colley reported that a local user can trigger an integer overflow in the sctp_setsockopt() option when the 'SCTP_SOCKOPT_DEBUG_NAME' socket option is set.  The flaw reportedly resides in 'net/sctp/socket.c', where an unsigned integer (optlen) that governs memory allocation may be incremented even when the integer is at its maximum value.  As a result, a remote user can supply a value such that the integer will overflow and the function will not allocate enough memory to hold the user-supplied 'optval' contents.  A subsequent copy_from_user() function call will then copy large amounts of user-supplied data to kernel memory, overwriting portions of kernel memory.

Stefan Esser reported that sys_setsockopt() first checks to ensure that optlen is not less than zero, so an integer overflow cannot occur.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel privileges.
Solution: A fix is available in 2.4.26 and 2.6 (where the vulnerable option has been removed).

Title: (SuSE Issues Fix) Linux Kernel cpufreq Signed Integer Assignment Flaw Discloses Memory to Local Users
Version(s): 8.0, 8.1, 8.2, 9.0, 9.1, SuSE Linux Database Server, SuSE eMail Server III, 3.1, SuSE Linux Enterprise Server 7, 8, SuSE Linux Firewall
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the cpufreq_userspace proc handler.  A local user may be able to read kernel memory.
Red Hat reported that the Linux kernel contains a signed integer boundary error in the cpufreq ioctl proc handler.  A user-supplied signed integer is cast to a signed integer and then used in copying memory.  As a result, a local user can read or write arbitrary amounts of kernel memory.

A local user can read arbitrary portions of kernel memory.  A root-level user can also write to arbitrary memory locations.

The flaw resides in 'drivers/cpufreq/cpufreq_userspace.c'.

Brad Spengler is credited with discovering this flaw.
Impact': A local user can read arbitrary portions of kernel memory.
Solution:
SuSE has released a fix.  See the Source Message for special kernel installation instructions.

Title: (SuSE Issues Fix) Linux Kernel setsockopt(2) MCAST_MSFILTER Integer Overflow Allows Local Users to Obtain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): 8.0, 8.1, 8.2, 9.0, 9.1, SuSE Linux Database Server, SuSE eMail Server III, 3.1, SuSE Linux Enterprise Server 7, 8, SuSE Linux Firewall
Description:
An integer overflow was reported in the Linux kernel in the setsockopt(2) system call.  A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Wojciech Purczynski of iSEC reported that a local user can call the ip_setsockopt()  function with the MCAST_MSFILTER option to trigger an integer overflow and execute arbitrary code or cause denial of service conditions.

The flaw resides in the 'net/ipv4/ip_sockglue.c' file, where the IP_MSFILTER_SIZE is not properly defined, the report said.

The vulnerable code was reportedly introduced into the kernel in the 2.4.22 and 2.6.1 kernel releases.

Paul Starzetz is credited with discovering the flaw.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0015-msfilter.txt
Impact':
A local user can execute arbitrary code on the target system with root privileges.

A local user can cause denial of service conditions (e.g., crash, reboot) on the target system.
Solution:
SuSE has released a fix.  See the Source Message for special kernel installation instructions.

Title: (SuSE Issues Fix) Linux Kernel do_fork() Memory Allocation Flaw Lets Local Users Consume Memory Resources and Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Version(s): 8.0, 8.1, 8.2, 9.0, 9.1, SuSE Linux Database Server, SuSE eMail Server III, 3.1, SuSE Linux Enterprise Server 7, 8, SuSE Linux Firewall
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the do_fork() function.  A local user may be able to cause denial of service conditions.
John Byrne reported that a local user can trigger an error in do_fork() after the mm_struct for the child has been allocated and the mm_count counter has been incremented such that the counter will not be decremented and the allocated memory will not be freed.

In the 'CLONE_VM' case, a similar error condition may occur, where the parent's mm_struct will have the mm_count incremented and never decremented.

Title: (Slackware Issues Fix) Linux Kernel setsockopt(2) MCAST_MSFILTER Integer Overflow Allows Local Users to Obtain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
An integer overflow was reported in the Linux kernel in the setsockopt(2) system call.  A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Wojciech Purczynski of iSEC reported that a local user can call the ip_setsockopt()  function with the MCAST_MSFILTER option to trigger an integer overflow and execute arbitrary code or cause denial of service conditions.

The flaw resides in the 'net/ipv4/ip_sockglue.c' file, where the IP_MSFILTER_SIZE is not properly defined, the report said.

The vulnerable code was reportedly introduced into the kernel in the 2.4.22 and 2.6.1 kernel releases.

Paul Starzetz is credited with discovering the flaw.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0015-msfilter.txt
Impact':
A local user can execute arbitrary code on the target system with root privileges.

A local user can cause denial of service conditions (e.g., crash, reboot) on the target system.
Solution:
Slackware has released a fix.

Title: (Engarde Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Buffer Overflow in ISO9660 File System Rock Ridge Extension Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): EnGarde Secure Community 2, EnGarde Secure Professional v1.5
Description:
iDEFENSE reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in the Linux kernel in the ISO9660 file system.  A local user can gain kernel level access on the system in certain cases.
It is reported that the kernel does not validate the length of symbolic links (symlinks) on ISO9660 file systems.

A local user can create and mount a CD that contains specially crafted symlinks to trigger the overflow in the kernel and execute arbitrary code.

The flaw can be triggered by performing a file or directory access on a specially crafted ISO9660 file system (such as a directory listing of file access), the report said.

The vulnerability reportedly resides in the support for the 'Rock Ridge' extension to the ISO9660 file system ('fs/isofs/rock.c') in the rock_ridge_symlink_readpage() and get_symlink_chunk() functions.

The vendor was reportedly notified on February 20, 2004.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel level privileges.
Solution: Guardian Digital has released a fix.  Guardian Digital Secure Network subscribers can update via the Guardian Digital WebTool.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Linux Kernel setsockopt(2) MCAST_MSFILTER Integer Overflow Allows Local Users to Obtain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
An integer overflow was reported in the Linux kernel in the setsockopt(2) system call.  A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Wojciech Purczynski of iSEC reported that a local user can call the ip_setsockopt()  function with the MCAST_MSFILTER option to trigger an integer overflow and execute arbitrary code or cause denial of service conditions.

The flaw resides in the 'net/ipv4/ip_sockglue.c' file, where the IP_MSFILTER_SIZE is not properly defined, the report said.

The vulnerable code was reportedly introduced into the kernel in the 2.4.22 and 2.6.1 kernel releases.

Paul Starzetz is credited with discovering the flaw.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0015-msfilter.txt
Impact':
A local user can execute arbitrary code on the target system with root privileges.

A local user can cause denial of service conditions (e.g., crash, reboot) on the target system.
Solution:
Mandrake has released a fix.

Title: Linux 2.6 Kernel fb_copy_cmap() Memory Access Flaw Has Unspecified Impact
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the framebuffer driver in the Linux 2.6 kernel.  The impact was not specified.
Several vendors reported that the fb_copy_cmap() function is not properly used and may directly access userspace memory.
Impact': The impace was not specified.
Solution: Individual vendors are issuing fixed versions for their respective distributions [See the Message History].

Title: Linux Kernel panic() Buffer Overflow Has Unspecified Impact
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Linux Kernel in the panic() function.  The impact was not specified.
Red Hat reported that there is a potential buffer overflow in the Linux kernel in the panic() function.  According to the report, the flaw is unlikely to be exploitable becuase the function does not return.

Shaun Colley is credited with discovering this flaw.
Impact': The impact was not specified.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

[See the Message History for separate alerts regarding fixes from individual Linux distribution vendors.]

Title: Linux Kernel cpufreq Signed Integer Assignment Flaw Discloses Memory to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the cpufreq_userspace proc handler.  A local user may be able to read kernel memory.
Red Hat reported that the Linux kernel contains a signed integer boundary error in the cpufreq ioctl proc handler.  A user-supplied signed integer is cast to a signed integer and then used in copying memory.  As a result, a local user can read or write arbitrary amounts of kernel memory.

A local user can read arbitrary portions of kernel memory.  A root-level user can also write to arbitrary memory locations.

The flaw resides in 'drivers/cpufreq/cpufreq_userspace.c'.

Brad Spengler is credited with discovering this flaw.
Impact': A local user can read arbitrary portions of kernel memory.
Solution: A fix is available in 'drivers/cpufreq/cpufreq_userspace.c' as of April 21, 2004.

Title: Linux Kernel setsockopt(2) MCAST_MSFILTER Integer Overflow Allows Local Users to Obtain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
An integer overflow was reported in the Linux kernel in the setsockopt(2) system call.  A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Wojciech Purczynski of iSEC reported that a local user can call the ip_setsockopt()  function with the MCAST_MSFILTER option to trigger an integer overflow and execute arbitrary code or cause denial of service conditions.

The flaw resides in the 'net/ipv4/ip_sockglue.c' file, where the IP_MSFILTER_SIZE is not properly defined, the report said.

The vulnerable code was reportedly introduced into the kernel in the 2.4.22 and 2.6.1 kernel releases.

Paul Starzetz is credited with discovering the flaw.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0015-msfilter.txt
Impact':
A local user can execute arbitrary code on the target system with root privileges.

A local user can cause denial of service conditions (e.g., crash, reboot) on the target system.
Solution: The vendor has issued a fixed version (2.4.26 and 2.6.4).

Version(s): Trustix Secure Linux 2.0, 2.1; Trustix Secure Enterprise Linux 2
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel JFS filesystem.  A local user with certain privileges can obtain small amounts of system memory contents.

Title: (Trustix Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Buffer Overflow in ISO9660 File System Rock Ridge Extension Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): Trustix Secure Linux 2.0, 2.1; Trustix Secure Enterprise Linux 2
Description:
iDEFENSE reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in the Linux kernel in the ISO9660 file system.  A local user can gain kernel level access on the system in certain cases.
It is reported that the kernel does not validate the length of symbolic links (symlinks) on ISO9660 file systems.

A local user can create and mount a CD that contains specially crafted symlinks to trigger the overflow in the kernel and execute arbitrary code.

The flaw can be triggered by performing a file or directory access on a specially crafted ISO9660 file system (such as a directory listing of file access), the report said.

The vulnerability reportedly resides in the support for the 'Rock Ridge' extension to the ISO9660 file system ('fs/isofs/rock.c') in the rock_ridge_symlink_readpage() and get_symlink_chunk() functions.

The vendor was reportedly notified on February 20, 2004.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel level privileges.
Solution:
Trustix has released a fix, available at:

http://http.trustix.org/pub/trustix/updates/
ftp://ftp.trustix.org/pub/trustix/updates/

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for 2.4.18/alpha/i386/powerpc) Linux Kernel Leaks System Memory to EXT3 Filesystem
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel ext3 filesystem.  A local user with certain privileges can obtain small amounts of system memory contents.
Debian, Mandrake, and Red Hat reported that there is an information leak in the Linux kernel ext3 code.  When the filesystem is created or written to, some system memory data is written to the device.

A local user with the ability to read the raw device may be able to read sensitive data such as cryptographic keys, the report said.

Solar Designer is credited with discovering this flaw.
Impact': A local user with privileges to read the raw device (that hosts the affected file system) can view small portions of system memory.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for 2.4.18/alpha/i386/powerpc) Linux Kernel Buffer Overflow in ISO9660 File System Rock Ridge Extension Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
iDEFENSE reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in the Linux kernel in the ISO9660 file system.  A local user can gain kernel level access on the system in certain cases.
It is reported that the kernel does not validate the length of symbolic links (symlinks) on ISO9660 file systems.

A local user can create and mount a CD that contains specially crafted symlinks to trigger the overflow in the kernel and execute arbitrary code.

The flaw can be triggered by performing a file or directory access on a specially crafted ISO9660 file system (such as a directory listing of file access), the report said.

The vulnerability reportedly resides in the support for the 'Rock Ridge' extension to the ISO9660 file system ('fs/isofs/rock.c') in the rock_ridge_symlink_readpage() and get_symlink_chunk() functions.

The vendor was reportedly notified on February 20, 2004.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel level privileges.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for 2.4.18/alpha/i386/powerpc) Linux Kernel ncpfs Stack Overflow Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.6 kernel in ncpfs.  A local user can gain elevated privileges on the target system.
It is reported that ncp_lookup() does not validate name component lengths.  A local user can cause data to overflow onto the stack, resulting in the execution of arbitrary code.

Arjan van de Ven is credited with discovering this flaw.

[Editor's note:  It is not clear if the 2.4 kernel or any other kernel series is affected.]
Impact': A local user can gain elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix for Fedora) Linux Kernel Buffer Overflow in ISO9660 File System Rock Ridge Extension Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
iDEFENSE reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in the Linux kernel in the ISO9660 file system.  A local user can gain kernel level access on the system in certain cases.
It is reported that the kernel does not validate the length of symbolic links (symlinks) on ISO9660 file systems.

A local user can create and mount a CD that contains specially crafted symlinks to trigger the overflow in the kernel and execute arbitrary code.

The flaw can be triggered by performing a file or directory access on a specially crafted ISO9660 file system (such as a directory listing of file access), the report said.

The vulnerability reportedly resides in the support for the 'Rock Ridge' extension to the ISO9660 file system ('fs/isofs/rock.c') in the rock_ridge_symlink_readpage() and get_symlink_chunk() functions.

The vendor was reportedly notified on February 20, 2004.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel level privileges.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix for Fedora) Linux Kernel Leaks System Memory to EXT3 Filesystem
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel ext3 filesystem.  A local user with certain privileges can obtain small amounts of system memory contents.
Debian, Mandrake, and Red Hat reported that there is an information leak in the Linux kernel ext3 code.  When the filesystem is created or written to, some system memory data is written to the device.

A local user with the ability to read the raw device may be able to read sensitive data such as cryptographic keys, the report said.

Solar Designer is credited with discovering this flaw.
Impact': A local user with privileges to read the raw device (that hosts the affected file system) can view small portions of system memory.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Linux Sound Blaster Driver Error Lets Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux Sound Blaster driver.  A local user may be able to cause the system to crash.
Debian and Mandrake reported a denial of service vulnerability in the Linux code for Sound Blaster 16 devices.  A local user with access to the sound system can cause the system to crash, the report said.

Andreas Kies is credited with discovering this flaw.
Impact': A local user with access to the sound system can cause the kernel to crash.
Solution:
Mandrake has released a fix.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Leaks System Memory to EXT3 Filesystem
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel ext3 filesystem.  A local user with certain privileges can obtain small amounts of system memory contents.
Debian, Mandrake, and Red Hat reported that there is an information leak in the Linux kernel ext3 code.  When the filesystem is created or written to, some system memory data is written to the device.

A local user with the ability to read the raw device may be able to read sensitive data such as cryptographic keys, the report said.

Solar Designer is credited with discovering this flaw.
Impact': A local user with privileges to read the raw device (that hosts the affected file system) can view small portions of system memory.
Solution:
Mandrake has released a fix.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Leaks System Memory to XFS Filesystem
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel XFS filesystem.  A local user with certain privileges can obtain small amounts of system memory contents.
Debian and Mandrake reported that there is an information leak in the Linux kernel XFS code.  When the filesystem is created or written to, some system memory data is written to the device.

A local user with the ability to read the raw device may be able to read sensitive data such as cryptographic keys, the report said.
Impact': A local user with privileges to read the raw device (that hosts the affected file system) can view small portions of system memory.
Solution:
Mandrake has released a fix.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Buffer Overflow in ISO9660 File System Rock Ridge Extension Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
iDEFENSE reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in the Linux kernel in the ISO9660 file system.  A local user can gain kernel level access on the system in certain cases.
It is reported that the kernel does not validate the length of symbolic links (symlinks) on ISO9660 file systems.

A local user can create and mount a CD that contains specially crafted symlinks to trigger the overflow in the kernel and execute arbitrary code.

The flaw can be triggered by performing a file or directory access on a specially crafted ISO9660 file system (such as a directory listing of file access), the report said.

The vulnerability reportedly resides in the support for the 'Rock Ridge' extension to the ISO9660 file system ('fs/isofs/rock.c') in the rock_ridge_symlink_readpage() and get_symlink_chunk() functions.

The vendor was reportedly notified on February 20, 2004.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel level privileges.
Solution:
Mandrake has released a fix.

Title: Linux Sound Blaster Driver Error Lets Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Version(s): 2.4.25 and prior versions; 2.6.5 and prior versions
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux Sound Blaster driver.  A local user may be able to cause the system to crash.
Debian and Mandrake reported a denial of service vulnerability in the Linux code for Sound Blaster 16 devices.  A local user with access to the sound system can cause the system to crash, the report said.

Andreas Kies is credited with discovering this flaw.
Impact': A local user with access to the sound system can cause the kernel to crash.
Solution: It appears that a fix is available in 2.4.26 and the latest 2.6.5 snapshot.

Title: Linux Kernel Leaks System Memory to JFS Filesystem
Version(s): 2.4.25 and prior versions; 2.6.5 and prior versions
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel JFS filesystem.  A local user with certain privileges can obtain small amounts of system memory contents.
Debian and Mandrake reported that there is an information leak in the Linux kernel JFS code.  When the filesystem is created or written to, some system memory data is written to the device.

A local user with the ability to read the raw device may be able to read sensitive data such as cryptographic keys, the report said.
Impact': A local user with privileges to read the raw device (that hosts the affected file system) can view small portions of system memory.
Solution: It appears that a fix is available in 2.4.26 and the latest 2.6.5 snapshot.

Title: Linux Kernel Buffer Overflow in ISO9660 File System Rock Ridge Extension Lets Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
iDEFENSE reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in the Linux kernel in the ISO9660 file system.  A local user can gain kernel level access on the system in certain cases.
It is reported that the kernel does not validate the length of symbolic links (symlinks) on ISO9660 file systems.

A local user can create and mount a CD that contains specially crafted symlinks to trigger the overflow in the kernel and execute arbitrary code.

The flaw can be triggered by performing a file or directory access on a specially crafted ISO9660 file system (such as a directory listing of file access), the report said.

The vulnerability reportedly resides in the support for the 'Rock Ridge' extension to the ISO9660 file system ('fs/isofs/rock.c') in the rock_ridge_symlink_readpage() and get_symlink_chunk() functions.

The vendor was reportedly notified on February 20, 2004.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with kernel level privileges.
Solution: A fix is available.  Linux distribution vendors are issuing separate advisories [see the Message History].

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for 2.4.18 HPPA) Linux Kernel do_mremap() Fails to Check do_munmap() Return Values, Allowing a Local User to Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Another vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Paul Starzetz discovered and reported that there is a missing return value check within the mremap(2) system call.

When resizing or moving virtual memory areas, the function reportedly does not test the return value of the do_munmap() function.  Cases where the function fails (for example, due to the number of virtual memory areas being exceeded by the calling process) will not be properly detected, according to the report.  As a result, the kernel may move memory belonging to one process into memory space that is allocated to another process.

Some other calls to the do_munmap() function are also not checked, the report said.

A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0014-mremap-unmap.txt
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for 2.4.18 HPPA) Linux Kernel mremap() Improper Bounds Checking Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Paul Starzetz and Wojciech Purczynski of iSEC Security Research reported that the mremap(2) system call does not perform proper bounds checking in the do_mremap() kernel code.  A local user can reportedly cause the kernel to remap memory and create a virtual memory area that is 0 bytes in length.

According to the report, a local user can gain root privileges on the system through non-trivial exploit methods.

The original advisory is available at:

Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.  A local user can also cause denial of service conditions on the system.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for 2.4.18 HPPA) Linux 2.4 Kernel do_brk() Input Validation Flaw Lets Local Users Grab Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user can gain root level privileges.
It is reported that the do_brk() function does not perform proper bounds checking.  A local user can run a userland application to cause the kernel to grant the local user access to the full kernel address space.  The userland application can create an arbitrary and large virtual memory area, exceeding user accessible memory limits (TASK_SIZE). 

Red Hat reports that an exploit for this flaw has been found in the wild.
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for HPPA) Linux 2.4 Kernel do_brk() Input Validation Flaw Lets Local Users Grab Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user can gain root level privileges.
It is reported that the do_brk() function does not perform proper bounds checking.  A local user can run a userland application to cause the kernel to grant the local user access to the full kernel address space.  The userland application can create an arbitrary and large virtual memory area, exceeding user accessible memory limits (TASK_SIZE).

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for PowerPC) Linux Kernel do_mremap() Fails to Check do_munmap() Return Values, Allowing a Local User to Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Another vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Paul Starzetz discovered and reported that there is a missing return value check within the mremap(2) system call.

When resizing or moving virtual memory areas, the function reportedly does not test the return value of the do_munmap() function.  Cases where the function fails (for example, due to the number of virtual memory areas being exceeded by the calling process) will not be properly detected, according to the report.  As a result, the kernel may move memory belonging to one process into memory space that is allocated to another process.

Some other calls to the do_munmap() function are also not checked, the report said.

A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0014-mremap-unmap.txt
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix.

Title: (SCO Issues Fix for OpenLinux) GNU/Linux '/bin/ls' Memory Allocation May Let Remote Users Deny Service Via Other Applications
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the GNU/Linux 'ls' utility.  A remote user may be able to cause denial of service conditions by exploiting /bin/ls via remote applications, such as wu-ftpd.
Georgi Guninski reported an integer overflow in /bin/ls.  Also, applications that invoke /bin/ls may be subject to denial of service attacks, the report said.  A remote user may be able to cause an application (such as wu-ftpd) to invoke ls with the '-w' column width option and the '-C' option to consume a large amount of memory for a temporary period of time.  The init_column_info() function will potentially allocate much more memory than is needed to display the relevant files.  This can reportedly cause temporary denial of service conditions.

As a demonstration exploit of the memory consumption flaw, the following command can be used via wu-ftpd:

ls "-w 1000000 -C"

As a demonstration exploit for the integer overflow flaw, the following local command can be used:

/bin/ls -w 1073741828 -C

The /bin/ls utility is part of the GNU coreutils collection.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.guninski.com/binls.html
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause applications using /bin/ls to experience denial of service conditions.
Solution:
SCO has issued the following fixes.

Title: GNU coreutils Integer Overflow in 'dir' Command Lets Local Users Deny Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the GNU Linux coreutils 'dir' command.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions and may be able to execute arbitrary code.
Shaun Colley reported an integer overflow in the 'dir' command, similar to a flaw in the 'ls' command reported by Georgi Guninski in October 2003 [and published in our Alert ID 1007981].

The flaw can be triggered when a specially crafted integer value is passed using the '-w' command line flag, resulting in stack corruption and 100% CPU utilization, the report said.

A demonstration exploit command is provided:

dir -w 1073741828
Impact': A local user can cause CPU utilization to reach 100%.
Solution:
The report indicates that the coreutils (or fileutils) patch to correct the previously reported integer overflow in the 'ls' command also prevents exploitation of this vulnerability.  As a result, version 5.2.0 is reportedly not vulnerable.  This version is available at:

http://ftp.gnu.org/pub/gnu/coreutils/
