Title: (Exploit Code is Available) Linux Kernel mremap() Improper Bounds Checking Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Paul Starzetz and Wojciech Purczynski of iSEC Security Research reported that the mremap(2) system call does not perform proper bounds checking in the do_mremap() kernel code. A local user can reportedly cause the kernel to remap memory and create a virtual memory area that is 0 bytes in length.

According to the report, a local user can gain root privileges on the system through non-trivial exploit methods.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0013-mremap.txt

A more detailed advisory, including demonstration exploit code, is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0014-mremap-unmap.txt
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.  A local user can also cause denial of service conditions on the system.
Solution: Fixes are reportedly available (or pending) for various Linux kernel distributions.  As the distributors release their fixes, separate Alerts will be issued [see the Message History].

Title: Linux Kernel strncpy() May Leak Kernel Memory to Local Processes
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel strncpy() function.  A userspace application may be able to obtain very small portions of kernel memory.
In July 2003, it was reported that the Linux kernel strncpy() implementation may pad the returned buffer with portions of kernel memory on non-x86 architecutres instead of padding the buffer with NULL characters.
Impact': The kernel may leak small portions of kernel memory to userspace applications.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of the original report.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for MIPS) Linux Kernel do_mremap() Fails to Check do_munmap() Return Values, Allowing a Local User to Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Another vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Paul Starzetz discovered and reported that there is a missing return value check within the mremap(2) system call.

When resizing or moving virtual memory areas, the function reportedly does not test the return value of the do_munmap() function.  Cases where the function fails (for example, due to the number of virtual memory areas being exceeded by the calling process) will not be properly detected, according to the report.  As a result, the kernel may move memory belonging to one process into memory space that is allocated to another process.

Some other calls to the do_munmap() function are also not checked, the report said.

A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0014-mremap-unmap.txt
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix for the stable distribution (woody) in version 2.4.19-0.020911.1.woody3 of mips images and version 2.4.19-4.woody1 of kernel source.

For the unstable distribution (sid), a fix will be available soon in the next upload of a 2.4.19 kernel image and in version 2.4.22-0.030928.3 for 2.4.22.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for MIPS) Linux 2.4 Kernel do_brk() Input Validation Flaw Lets Local Users Grab Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user can gain root level privileges.
It is reported that the do_brk() function does not perform proper bounds checking.  A local user can run a userland application to cause the kernel to grant the local user access to the full kernel address space.  The userland application can create an arbitrary and large virtual memory area, exceeding user accessible memory limits (TASK_SIZE). 

Red Hat reports that an exploit for this flaw has been found in the wild.
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix for the stable distribution (woody) in version 2.4.19-0.020911.1.woody3 of mips images and version 2.4.19-4.woody1 of kernel source.

For the unstable distribution (sid), a fix will be available soon in the next upload of a 2.4.19 kernel image and in version 2.4.22-0.030928.3 for 2.4.22.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix for x86_64) Linux Kernel do_mremap() Fails to Check do_munmap() Return Values, Allowing a Local User to Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Another vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Paul Starzetz discovered and reported that there is a missing return value check within the mremap(2) system call.

When resizing or moving virtual memory areas, the function reportedly does not test the return value of the do_munmap() function.  Cases where the function fails (for example, due to the number of virtual memory areas being exceeded by the calling process) will not be properly detected, according to the report.  As a result, the kernel may move memory belonging to one process into memory space that is allocated to another process.

Some other calls to the do_munmap() function are also not checked, the report said.

A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0014-mremap-unmap.txt
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Mandrake has released a fix.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for ia64 Architecture) Linux Kernel do_mremap() Fails to Check do_munmap() Return Values, Allowing a Local User to Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Another vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Paul Starzetz discovered and reported that there is a missing return value check within the mremap(2) system call.

When resizing or moving virtual memory areas, the function reportedly does not test the return value of the do_munmap() function.  Cases where the function fails (for example, due to the number of virtual memory areas being exceeded by the calling process) will not be properly detected, according to the report.  As a result, the kernel may move memory belonging to one process into memory space that is allocated to another process.

Some other calls to the do_munmap() function are also not checked, the report said.

A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0014-mremap-unmap.txt
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix for the stable distribution (woody) in version 011226.16 of ia64 kernel source and images.

Title: (SuSE Issues Fix) Linux Kernel do_mremap() Fails to Check do_munmap() Return Values, Allowing a Local User to Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): 8.0, 8.1, 8.2, 9.0, SuSE Linux Database Server, SuSE eMail Server III, 3.1, SuSE Linux Enterprise Server 7, 8, SuSE Linux Firewall on CD/Admin host, SuSE Linux Connectivity Server, SuSE Linux Office Server
Description:
Another vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Paul Starzetz discovered and reported that there is a missing return value check within the mremap(2) system call.

When resizing or moving virtual memory areas, the function reportedly does not test the return value of the do_munmap() function.  Cases where the function fails (for example, due to the number of virtual memory areas being exceeded by the calling process) will not be properly detected, according to the report.  As a result, the kernel may move memory belonging to one process into memory space that is allocated to another process.

Some other calls to the do_munmap() function are also not checked, the report said.

A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0014-mremap-unmap.txt
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
SuSE has released a fix.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix for RH Enterprise Linux) Linux Kernel do_mremap() Fails to Check do_munmap() Return Values, Allowing a Local User to Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Another vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Paul Starzetz discovered and reported that there is a missing return value check within the mremap(2) system call.

When resizing or moving virtual memory areas, the function reportedly does not test the return value of the do_munmap() function.  Cases where the function fails (for example, due to the number of virtual memory areas being exceeded by the calling process) will not be properly detected, according to the report.  As a result, the kernel may move memory belonging to one process into memory space that is allocated to another process.

Some other calls to the do_munmap() function are also not checked, the report said.

A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0014-mremap-unmap.txt
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Red Hat has released a fix.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for mips/mipsel) Linux Kernel do_mremap() Fails to Check do_munmap() Return Values, Allowing a Local User to Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Another vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Paul Starzetz discovered and reported that there is a missing return value check within the mremap(2) system call.

When resizing or moving virtual memory areas, the function reportedly does not test the return value of the do_munmap() function.  Cases where the function fails (for example, due to the number of virtual memory areas being exceeded by the calling process) will not be properly detected, according to the report.  As a result, the kernel may move memory belonging to one process into memory space that is allocated to another process.

Some other calls to the do_munmap() function are also not checked, the report said.

A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0014-mremap-unmap.txt
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix for the stable distribution (woody) in version 2.4.17-0.020226.2.woody5 for mips and mipsel kernel images.

For the unstable distribution (sid), this flaw will reportedly be fixed soon with the next upload of a 2.4.19 kernel image and in version 2.4.22-0.030928.3 for 2.4.22 for the mips and mipsel architectures.

Title: (Slackware Issues Fix) Linux Kernel do_mremap() Fails to Check do_munmap() Return Values, Allowing a Local User to Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Another vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Paul Starzetz discovered and reported that there is a missing return value check within the mremap(2) system call.

When resizing or moving virtual memory areas, the function reportedly does not test the return value of the do_munmap() function.  Cases where the function fails (for example, due to the number of virtual memory areas being exceeded by the calling process) will not be properly detected, according to the report.  As a result, the kernel may move memory belonging to one process into memory space that is allocated to another process.

Some other calls to the do_munmap() function are also not checked, the report said.

A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0014-mremap-unmap.txt
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Slackware has released a fix for Slackware 9.1.  The vendor reports that the kernels in Slackware 8.1 and 9.0 that were updated in January 2004 are not vulnerable to this new flaw, as the patch that fixed CVE-2003-0985 also fixes this new flaw.

Users running Slackware 9.1 or -current should upgrade to a new kernel.  After installing the new kernel, users are reminded to run 'lilo'.

Title: Linux Kernel Vicam USB Driver May Cross Security Boundaries and Access Userspace Data
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the Vicam USB driver.  A local process may be able to cross security boundaries.
It is reported that the Vicam USB driver in Linux kernel versions prior to 2.4.25 does not use the copy_from_user() function to access userspace, which violates security boundaries.

No further details were provided.
Impact': A local process may be able to cause the driver to access userspace data for a different process.
Solution:
A fixed version (2.4.25) is planned, to be available at:

http://www.kernel.org/

Title: Linux Kernel do_mremap() Fails to Check do_munmap() Return Values, Allowing a Local User to Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Another vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Paul Starzetz discovered and reported that there is a missing return value check within the mremap(2) system call.

When resizing or moving virtual memory areas, the function reportedly does not test the return value of the do_munmap() function.  Cases where the function fails (for example, due to the number of virtual memory areas being exceeded by the calling process) will not be properly detected, according to the report.  As a result, the kernel may move memory belonging to one process into memory space that is allocated to another process.

Some other calls to the do_munmap() function are also not checked, the report said.

A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0014-mremap-unmap.txt
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
A fixed kernel version (2.4.25, 2.6.3) is available at:

http://www.kernel.org/

Title: Linux Kernel ncpfs Stack Overflow Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.6 kernel in ncpfs.  A local user can gain elevated privileges on the target system.
It is reported that ncp_lookup() does not validate name component lengths.  A local user can cause data to overflow onto the stack, resulting in the execution of arbitrary code.

Arjan van de Ven is credited with discovering this flaw.

[Editor's note:  It is not clear if the 2.4 kernel or any other kernel series is affected.]
Impact': A local user can gain elevated privileges on the target system.
Solution:
A fix is included in Linux Kernel 2.6.3, available at:

http://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/kernel/v2.6/patch-2.6.3.bz2

Title: (Gentoo Issues Fix) Linux AMD64 Kernel eflags Error May Yield Root Privileges to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel on AMD64-based systems in the processing of eflags.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
Red Hat originally reported that there is a flaw in the eflags checking in 32-bit ptrace emulation mode.  No further details were provided.
Impact': A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges, including root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
Gentoo has released a fix and encourages users to upgrade to the latest available sources for their system:

~  # emerge sync
~  # emerge -pv your-favorite-sources

~  # emerge your-favorite-sources

~  # # Follow usual procedures for compiling and installing a kernel.
~  # # If you use genkernel, run genkernel as you would do normally.

~  # # See http://www.gentoo.org/doc/en/handbook/handbook.xml for help.

Title: (Sun Issues Fix for Sun Linux) Linux Kernel mremap() Improper Bounds Checking Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Paul Starzetz and Wojciech Purczynski of iSEC Security Research reported that the mremap(2) system call does not perform proper bounds checking in the do_mremap() kernel code.  A local user can reportedly cause the kernel to remap memory and create a virtual memory area that is 0 bytes in length.

According to the report, a local user can gain root privileges on the system through non-trivial exploit methods.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0013-mremap.txt
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.  A local user can also cause denial of service conditions on the system.
Solution:
Sun has issued a Linux kernel update (Sun Linux 5.0.9 [Update 1]), available at:

ftp://ftp.cobalt.sun.com/pub/products/sunlinux/5.0/en/updates/i386/update_5_0_9/
ftp://ftp.cobalt.sun.com/pub/products/sunlinux/5.0/en/updates/i386/update_5_0_9/Sun_Linux_5.0.9_update1.tar.bz2

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix for RH Enterprise Linux) Linux Kernel Buffer Overflow in IXJ Telephony Card Driver May Yield Root Privileges to Local Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the ixj telephony card driver.  A local user may be able to gain root privileges.
In October 2002, it was reported that Linux kernels prior to 2.4.20 contain a buffer overflow in the ixj telephony card driver.

No further details were provided.

[Editor's note:  It appears that the CVE-2002-1574 entry relates to the ixj buffer overflow first reported (publicly) in October 2002 in Red Hat security advisories RHSA-2002:205-15 and RHSA-2002:206-12, but that has not yet been confirmed.  The CVE listing for CVE-2002-1574 at the time of this message mentions only RHSA-2004:044, released in February 2004.]
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution:
Red Hat has released a fix.

Title: Linux Kernel Buffer Overflow in IXJ Telephony Card Driver May Yield Root Privileges to Local Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the ixj telephony card driver.  A local user may be able to gain root privileges.
In October 2002, it was reported that Linux kernels prior to 2.4.20 contain a buffer overflow in the ixj telephony card driver.

No further details were provided.

[Editor's note:  It appears that the CVE-2002-1574 entry relates to the ixj buffer overflow first reported (publicly) in October 2002 in Red Hat security advisories RHSA-2002:205-15 and RHSA-2002:206-12, but that has not yet been confirmed.  The CVE listing for CVE-2002-1574 at the time of this message mentions only RHSA-2004:044, released in February 2004.]
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution: A fix is available in Linux kernel version 2.4.20.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for MIPS) Linux 2.4 Kernel do_brk() Input Validation Flaw Lets Local Users Grab Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user can gain root level privileges.
It is reported that the do_brk() function does not perform proper bounds checking.  A local user can run a userland application to cause the kernel to grant the local user access to the full kernel address space.  The userland application can create an arbitrary and large virtual memory area, exceeding user accessible memory limits (TASK_SIZE). 

Red Hat reports that an exploit for this flaw has been found in the wild.
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix for the MIPS architecture for the stable distribution (woody) in version 2.4.17-0.020226.2.woody4.

Title: Linux Kernel C-Media PCI Audio Driver May Cross Security Boundaries and Access Userspace Data
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the C-Media PCI sound driver.  A local process may be able to cross security boundaries.
In July 2003, it was reported that the C-Media PCI sound driver accesses userspace without using the get_user function in certain cases.

This flaw is reportedly different than the C-Media PCI driver flaw reported in CVE CVE-2003-0699 [Alert ID 1007556].

No further details were provided.
Impact': A local process may be able to cause the driver to access userspace data for a different process.
Solution: The vendor has reportedly issued a fix in the Linux kernel version 2.4.22.

Title: Linux AMD64 Kernel eflags Error May Yield Root Privileges to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel on AMD64-based systems in the processing of eflags.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges.
Red Hat originally reported that there is a flaw in the eflags checking in 32-bit ptrace emulation mode.  No further details were provided.
Impact': A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges, including root privileges on the target system.
Solution:
It is not clear if an upstream fix is available at the time of this entry.

[Editor's note:  As Linux kernel distributors that are affected by this AMD64 issue release fixes, we will issue separate Alerts (see the Message History)].

Title: (Debian Issues Fix for IA64) Linux Kernel mremap() Improper Bounds Checking Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Paul Starzetz and Wojciech Purczynski of iSEC Security Research reported that the mremap(2) system call does not perform proper bounds checking in the do_mremap() kernel code.  A local user can reportedly cause the kernel to remap memory and create a virtual memory area that is 0 bytes in length.

According to the report, a local user can gain root privileges on the system through non-trivial exploit methods.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0013-mremap.txt
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.  A local user can also cause denial of service conditions on the system.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Real-time Clock Routines May Leak Kernel Data to User Applications

Solution:
Mandrake has released a fix.

Title: (Debian Issues Fix) Linux Kernel mremap() Improper Bounds Checking Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Paul Starzetz and Wojciech Purczynski of iSEC Security Research reported that the mremap(2) system call does not perform proper bounds checking in the do_mremap() kernel code.  A local user can reportedly cause the kernel to remap memory and create a virtual memory area that is 0 bytes in length.

According to the report, a local user can gain root privileges on the system through non-trivial exploit methods.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0013-mremap.txt
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.  A local user can also cause denial of service conditions on the system.
Solution:
Debian has released a fix for the stable distribution (woody) in kernel-source version 2.4.18-14.1 and kernel-images versions 2.4.18-12.1 and 2.4.18-5woody6 (bf) for the i386 architecture.  A fix for the unstable distribution (sid) will be available soon.

Title: (SuSE Issues Fix) Linux Kernel mremap() Improper Bounds Checking Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): 8.0, 8.1, 8.2, 9.0, SuSE Linux Enterprise Server 7, SuSE Linux Database Server, SuSE eMail Server III, 3.1, SuSE Linux Firewall on CD/Admin host, SuSE Linux Office Server, SuSE Linux Desktop 1.0, SuSE Linux School Server
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Paul Starzetz and Wojciech Purczynski of iSEC Security Research reported that the mremap(2) system call does not perform proper bounds checking in the do_mremap() kernel code.  A local user can reportedly cause the kernel to remap memory and create a virtual memory area that is 0 bytes in length.

According to the report, a local user can gain root privileges on the system through non-trivial exploit methods.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0013-mremap.txt
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.  A local user can also cause denial of service conditions on the system.
Solution:
SuSE has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing specific directions on how to apply the appropriate fix.

Title: (Trustix Issues Fix) Linux Kernel mremap() Improper Bounds Checking Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Paul Starzetz and Wojciech Purczynski of iSEC Security Research reported that the mremap(2) system call does not perform proper bounds checking in the do_mremap() kernel code.  A local user can reportedly cause the kernel to remap memory and create a virtual memory area that is 0 bytes in length.

According to the report, a local user can gain root privileges on the system through non-trivial exploit methods.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0013-mremap.txt
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.  A local user can also cause denial of service conditions on the system.
Solution:
Trustix has released a fix, available at:

http://http.trustix.org/pub/trustix/updates/
ftp://ftp.trustix.org/pub/trustix/updates/

SWUP tool users can update automatically:

'swup --upgrade'

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix for Red Hat Linux) Linux Kernel mremap() Improper Bounds Checking Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Paul Starzetz and Wojciech Purczynski of iSEC Security Research reported that the mremap(2) system call does not perform proper bounds checking in the do_mremap() kernel code.  A local user can reportedly cause the kernel to remap memory and create a virtual memory area that is 0 bytes in length.

According to the report, a local user can gain root privileges on the system through non-trivial exploit methods.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0013-mremap.txt
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.  A local user can also cause denial of service conditions on the system.
Solution:
Red Hat has released a fix.

Title: Linux Kernel Real-time Clock Routines May Leak Kernel Data to User Applications
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel in the real-time clock routines.  A local user may be able to view leaked kernel data.
In December 2003, it was reported that real time clock routines in the Linux kernel do not properly initialize memory structures.  As a result, a local user may be able to access the routines to view kernel stack data.
Impact': A local user may be able to view some kernel data.
Solution: Fixes are reportedly available (or pending) for various Linux kernel distributions. As the distributors release their fixes, separate Alerts will be issued [see the Message History].

Title: Linux Kernel mremap() Improper Bounds Checking Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel do_mremap() function.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.
Paul Starzetz and Wojciech Purczynski of iSEC Security Research reported that the mremap(2) system call does not perform proper bounds checking in the do_mremap() kernel code.  A local user can reportedly cause the kernel to remap memory and create a virtual memory area that is 0 bytes in length.

According to the report, a local user can gain root privileges on the system through non-trivial exploit methods.

The original advisory is available at:

http://isec.pl/vulnerabilities/isec-0013-mremap.txt
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.  A local user can also cause denial of service conditions on the system.
Solution: Fixes are reportedly available (or pending) for various Linux kernel distributions.  As the distributors release their fixes, separate Alerts will be issued [see the Message History].

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix for Conectiva 8) Linux 2.4 Kernel Route Cache Flaw Allows Remote Users to Cause Denial of Service Conditions
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 operating system kernel route cache hash table.  A remote user can send specially crafted packets to cause excessive CPU utilization and denial of service conditions.
It is reported that the kernel and the Netfilter IP conntrack module hash table implementations contain a flaw.  Other hash table implementations within the kernel may also be affected.  A remote user can send packets with specially crafted and invalid source addresses to cause hash collisions, with every routing cache entry hashed into the same hash chain.  This will cause the kernel to consume excessive CPU resources and can result in denial of service conditions.

According to the report, on a target host using 1 GB of RAM, a stream of 400 packets per second can cause the host to freeze.
Impact': A remote user can cause the kernel to freeze.
Solution:
Conectiva has released a fix.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix for Conectiva 8) Linux 2.4 Kernel Bug in ioperm() Gives Local Users Access to Restricted I/O Ports
Description:

Some demonstration exploit code is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can gain read and write access to restricted I/O ports.
Solution:
Conectiva has released a fix.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix for Conectiva 8) Linux 2.4 Kernel NFSv3 Integer Overflow May Let Remote Users Cause a Kernel Panic
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
An unsigned integer overflow was reported in the Linux kernel in an NFSv3 function call.  A remote user may be able to cause the system to crash.  The specific impact depends on the application or service that uses the vulnerable call.
It is reported that the decode_fh() function in the 'fs/nfsd/nfs3xdr.c' file may permit a remote user to supply XDR data that will cause a negative integer value to be processed by a kernel memcpy call.  This will trigger a kernel panic, according to the report.

Some demonstration exploit code is provided in the Source Message [it is Base64 encoded].
Impact': A remote or local user may be able to cause denial of service conditions on the system.
Solution:
Conectiva has released a fix.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) Linux 2.4 Kernel execve() Access Control Flaw May Let Local Users Access File Descriptors
Description:
An access control vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user may be able to gain access to restricted file descriptors.
It is reported that execve() records the file descriptor of an executable process in the calling process's file table.  A local user may be able to gain access to an otherwise restricted file descriptor.
Impact': A local user may be able to gain read access to file descriptors.
Solution:
Conectiva has released a fix.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) Linux 2.4 Kernel RPC Bug Lets Local Users Bind to Ports Already in Use
Description:
An access control vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user can bind services to UDP ports that have already been allocated.
It is reported that a change made recently to the Linux kernel in the remote procedure call (RPC) code implementation may cause the 'reuse' flag to be set on newly created sockets.  A local user can bind to UDP ports that have already been bound to a service (such as nfsd).

Olaf Kirch is credited with reporting this flaw.

[Editor's note:  The Red Hat report did not indicate which kernel version introduced this flaw.]
Impact': A local user can bind to UDP ports already in use by other services.
Solution:
Conectiva has released a fix.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) Linux 2.4 Kernel Spanning Tree Protocol Bug Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel in the Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) implementation.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
It is reported that the STP implementation does not properly validate the length of user-supplied input.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.

It is also reported that a remote user can modify the bridge topology [due to the inherent insecurity of the STP protocol].
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
Solution:
Conectiva has released a fix.

Description:

It is reported that a local user can exploit a flaw in the '/proc' filesystem to execute a set user id (setuid) program and view opened entries in '/proc/self'.  The files can be viewed with setuid privileges.
Impact': A local user may be able to view opened files in '/proc/self' with setuid privileges.
Solution:
Conectiva has released a fix.

Title: (Gentoo Issues Fix) Linux 2.4 Kernel do_brk() Input Validation Flaw Lets Local Users Grab Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user can gain root level privileges.
It is reported that the do_brk() function does not perform proper bounds checking.  A local user can run a userland application to cause the kernel to grant the local user access to the full kernel address space.  The userland application can create an arbitrary and large virtual memory area, exceeding user accessible memory limits (TASK_SIZE). 

Red Hat reports that an exploit for this flaw has been found in the wild.
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges.
Solution:
Gentoo has released a fix and recommends that all Gentoo Linux users upgrade their machines to use a kernel from the list [in the Source Message].

        emerge sync
        emerge -pv [your preferred kernel sources]
        emerge [your preferred kernel sources]
        [update the /usr/src/linux symlink]
        [compile and install your new kernel]
        [emerge any necessary kernel module ebuilds]
        [reboot]

Title: (Turbolinux Issues Fix) Linux Kernel 'd_path' Truncation Flaw May Allow a Local User to Cause a Privileged Process to Operate on an Arbitrary Directory Path
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux operating system kernel.  A local user may be able to trick a privileged process into thinking that it is operating with a different directory.
It is reported that the kernel d_path() function may return a truncated path name instead of an error value for long path names. This function is apparently called by the getcwd(2) system call and the do_proc_readlink() function.  User-space processes that implement these calls may receive incorrect information regarding directory paths.

It is reported that that the d_path kernel function resolves a string that is a concatenation of subsequent path components starting from the trailing path component into a 'dentry'. The concatenated path name is apparently stored in a fixed-length buffer of PAGE_SIZE bytes.  If a dentry points to a path that exceeds PAGE_SIZE - 1 characters length, leading path components are not written to the buffer and function instead returns truncated path without an error value, according to the report.

A local user may be able to cause a privileged process to interpret that the proper directory name is an arbitrary directory.

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user may be able to cause a privileged process to interpret that the proper directory name is an arbitrary directory.  The process may read or write to the wrong directory.

Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user can gain root level privileges.
It is reported that the do_brk() function does not perform proper bounds checking.  A local user can run a userland application to cause the kernel to grant the local user access to the full kernel address space.  The userland application can create an arbitrary and large virtual memory area, exceeding user accessible memory limits (TASK_SIZE). 

Red Hat reports that an exploit for this flaw has been found in the wild.
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges.

Red Hat has released a fix for Red Hat Linux.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Linux 2.4 Kernel do_brk() Input Validation Flaw Lets Local Users Grab Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): Mandrake Linux 9.0, 9.1, Corporate Server 2.1, Multi Network Firewall 8.2
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user can gain root level privileges.
It is reported that the do_brk() function does not perform proper bounds checking.  A local user can run a userland application to cause the kernel to grant the local user access to the full kernel address space.  The userland application can create an arbitrary and large virtual memory area, exceeding user accessible memory limits (TASK_SIZE). 

Red Hat reports that an exploit for this flaw has been found in the wild.
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges.
Solution:
Mandrake has released a fix.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix for Enterprise Linux) Linux 2.4 Kernel do_brk() Input Validation Flaw Lets Local Users Grab Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user can gain root level privileges.
It is reported that the do_brk() function does not perform proper bounds checking.  A local user can run a userland application to cause the kernel to grant the local user access to the full kernel address space.  The userland application can create an arbitrary and large virtual memory area, exceeding user accessible memory limits (TASK_SIZE). 

Red Hat reports that an exploit for this flaw has been found in the wild.
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges.
Solution:
Red Hat has released a fix.

Title: (Turbolinux Issues Fix) Re: GNU/Linux '/bin/ls' Memory Allocation May Let Remote Users Deny Service Via Other Applications
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Version(s): Turbolinux 10 Desktop, Turbolinux 8 Server, Turbolinux 8 Workstation, Turbolinux 7 Server, Turbolinux 7 Workstation, Turbolinux Server 6.5, Turbolinux Advanced Server 6, Turbolinux Server 6.1, Turbolinux Workstation 6.0
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the GNU/Linux 'ls' utility.  A remote user may be able to cause denial of service conditions by exploiting /bin/ls via remote applications, such as wu-ftpd.
Georgi Guninski reported an integer overflow in /bin/ls.  Also, applications that invoke /bin/ls may be subject to denial of service attacks, the report said.  A remote user may be able to cause an application (such as wu-ftpd) to invoke ls with the '-w' column width option and the '-C' option to consume a large amount of memory for a temporary period of time.  The init_column_info() function will potentially allocate much more memory than is needed to display the relevant files.  This can reportedly cause temporary denial of service conditions.

As a demonstration exploit of the memory consumption flaw, the following command can be used via wu-ftpd:

ls "-w 1000000 -C"

As a demonstration exploit for the integer overflow flaw, the following local command can be used:

/bin/ls -w 1073741828 -C

The /bin/ls utility is part of the GNU coreutils collection.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.guninski.com/binls.html
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause applications using /bin/ls to experience denial of service conditions.
Solution:
Turbolinux has issued a fix.

Title: Linux Kernel C-Media PCI Audio Driver Does Not Properly Access Userspace Data
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel in the C-Media PCI sound driver.  The driver does not properly separate userspace and kernel space data.
It is reported that 'cmpci.c' accesses some userspace arguments without using the get_user() function to copy the userspace data to kernel space.

No specific exploit method was described.
Impact': No specific impact was reported.  It may (theoretically) be possible for a local user to execute arbitrary code with kernel level privileges or to read kernel data.
Solution: The vendor has released a fixed version (2.4.21) of the Linux kernel.

Title: Linux Netfilter With Network Address Translation (NAT) Can Be Crashed By Remote Users in Certain Cases
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the network address translation (NAT) implementation in Netfilter.  A remote user may be able to cause the target system to crash.
It is reported that under certain circumstances, a remote user can send FTP or IRC packets to cause the system to crash.

If the affected kernel is configured with the CONFIG_IP_NF_NAT_FTP or CONFIG_IP_NF_NAT_IRC options enabled or if the ip_nat_ftp or ip_nat_irc modules are loadedloaded and FTP and IRC services are not filtered, the vulnerability can be triggered.
Impact': A remote user can cause the system to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix in Linux kernel 2.4.21.  Also, a patch for 2.4.20 is available in the Source Message and at the Vendor URL.

As a workaround, the vendor indicates that the affected modules can be removed or iptables can be used to block FTP and IRC connections.

According to the report, all of 2.4.20-based kernels shipped by Red Hat include the fix alread.

Title: Netfilter Connection Tracking Flaw Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Netfilter in the connection tracking function.  On certain versions of the Linux kernel, a remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
According to the report, only systems running the Linux 2.4.20 kernel are affected.  Previous and more recent versions are not affected.

If the CONFIG_IP_NF_CONNTRACK configuration option is enabled or if the ip_conntrack module is loaded on that particular kernel version, the system may be vulnerable.

The 2.4.20 kernel reportedly introduced a new method for providing linked list support, but the netfilter code was relying on the old method to identify 'UNCONFIRMED' connections (i.e., those that have only been detected in one direction).  These 'UNCONFIRMED' connects are reportedly assigned a "very high" timeout.  As a result, a remote user can generate traffic that will be labeled as 'UNCONFIRMED' by the netfilter code to consume memory on the target system.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version, available in Linux kernel 2.4.21.  Patches for kernel version 2.4.20 are also provided in the Source Message and at the Vendor URL.

As a workaround, the vendor indicates that you should not use connection tracking on kernel versions 2.4.20.

Title: Linux 'lockdev' May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in lockdev.  A local user may be able to obtain elevated privileges on the system.
0x333 Outsiders Security Labs reported that there is a buffer overflow in the 'setup.c' file.  A local user can cause a segmentation fault.

The report did not confirm that code execution is possible.  According to the report, the application may be installed with set group id (setgid) 'lock' group privileges.  If code execution is possible, a local user can gain 'lock' group privileges.
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with 'lock' group privileges (however, code execution was not confirmed in the report).
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Linux 2.4 Kernel NFSv3 Integer Overflow May Let Remote Users Cause a Kernel Panic
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
An unsigned integer overflow was reported in the Linux kernel in an NFSv3 function call.  A remote user may be able to cause the system to crash.  The specific impact depends on the application or service that uses the vulnerable call.
It is reported that the decode_fh() function in the 'fs/nfsd/nfs3xdr.c' file may permit a remote user to supply XDR data that will cause a negative integer value to be processed by a kernel memcpy call.  This will trigger a kernel panic, according to the report.

Some demonstration exploit code is provided in the Source Message [it is Base64 encoded].
Impact': A remote or local user may be able to cause denial of service conditions on the system.
Solution: According to the report, this flaw was fixed in version 2.4.21.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux 2.4 Kernel Forwarding Table Can Be Spoofed By Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel forwarding table.  A remote user can send spoofed packets.
It is reported that a remote user can send packets with a forged source address of the localhost to spoof the forwarding table.

Jerry Kreuscher is credited with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can send spoofed packets that may be incorrectly processed by the forwarding table.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux 2.4 Kernel '/proc/self' Error May Disclose Sensitive Information to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the '/proc' filesystem of the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user may be able to view sensitive information on the system.
It is reported that a local user can exploit a flaw in the '/proc' filesystem to execute a set user id (setuid) program and view opened entries in '/proc/self'.  The files can be viewed with setuid privileges.
Impact': A local user may be able to view opened files in '/proc/self' with setuid privileges.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux 2.4 Kernel execve() Access Control Flaw May Let Local Users Access File Descriptors
Description:
An access control vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user may be able to gain access to restricted file descriptors.
It is reported that execve() records the file descriptor of an executable process in the calling process's file table.  A local user may be able to gain access to an otherwise restricted file descriptor.
Impact': A local user may be able to gain read access to file descriptors.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux 2.4 Kernel RPC Bug Lets Local Users Bind to Ports Already in Use
Description:
An access control vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user can bind services to UDP ports that have already been allocated.
It is reported that a change made recently to the Linux kernel in the remote procedure call (RPC) code implementation may cause the 'reuse' flag to be set on newly created sockets.  A local user can bind to UDP ports that have already been bound to a service (such as nfsd).

Olaf Kirch is credited with reporting this flaw.

[Editor's note:  The Red Hat report did not indicate which kernel version introduced this flaw.]
Impact': A local user can bind to UDP ports already in use by other services.
Solution:
Red Hat has released the following fixes:

Red Hat Linux 7.1:

SRPMS:

Title: Linux 2.4 Kernel Forwarding Table Can Be Spoofed By Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel forwarding table.  A remote user can send spoofed packets.
It is reported that a remote user can send packets with a forged source address of the localhost to spoof the forwarding table.

Jerry Kreuscher is credited with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can send spoofed packets that may be incorrectly processed by the forwarding table.
Solution: It is not clear if an upstream fix is available yet. Fixes for individual kernel distributions are pending. Check the Message History for fixes from various kernel vendors.

Title: Linux 2.4 Kernel '/proc/self' Error May Disclose Sensitive Information to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the '/proc' filesystem of the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user may be able to view sensitive information on the system.
It is reported that a local user can exploit a flaw in the '/proc' filesystem to execute a set user id (setuid) program and view opened entries in '/proc/self'.  The files can be viewed with setuid privileges.
Impact': A local user may be able to view opened files in '/proc/self' with setuid privileges.
Solution: It is not clear if an upstream fix is available yet. Fixes for individual kernel distributions are pending. Check the Message History for fixes from various kernel vendors.

Title: Linux 2.4 Kernel execve() Access Control Flaw May Let Local Users Access File Descriptors
Description:
An access control vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user may be able to gain access to restricted file descriptors.
It is reported that execve() records the file descriptor of an executable process in the calling process's file table.  A local user may be able to gain access to an otherwise restricted file descriptor.
Impact': A local user may be able to gain read access to file descriptors.
Solution: It is not clear if an upstream fix is available yet. Fixes for individual kernel distributions are pending. Check the Message History for fixes from various kernel vendors.

Title: Linux 2.4 Kernel RPC Bug Lets Local Users Bind to Ports Already in Use
Description:
An access control vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user can bind services to UDP ports that have already been allocated.
It is reported that a change made recently to the Linux kernel in the remote procedure call (RPC) code implementation may cause the 'reuse' flag to be set on newly created sockets.  A local user can bind to UDP ports that have already been bound to a service (such as nfsd).

Olaf Kirch is credited with reporting this flaw.

[Editor's note:  The Red Hat report did not indicate which kernel version introduced this flaw.]
Impact': A local user can bind to UDP ports already in use by other services.
Solution: It is not clear if an upstream fix is available yet. Fixes for individual kernel distributions are pending. Check the Message History for fixes from various kernel vendors.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux 2.4 Kernel execve() Race Condition May Let Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system

A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user may be able to crash the system.
It is reported that a local user can exploit a file read race condition in the execve() system call to trigger a crash.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux 2.4 Kernel /proc/tty/driver/serial May Disclose Password Characteristics to Local Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A flaw in '/proc/tty/driver/serial' may let local users gain information about password characteristics.
It is reported that '/proc/tty/driver/serial discloses the exact character counts for information on the serial links.  A local user can monitor this object to attempt to determine the length of a target user's password (as typed) and keystroke timing, which can yield information about the target user's password.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain information about password lengths and password keystroke timing.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux 2.4 Kernel Spanning Tree Protocol Bug Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel in the Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) implementation.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
It is reported that the STP implementation does not properly validate the length of user-supplied input.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.

It is also reported that a remote user can modify the bridge topology [due to the inherent insecurity of the STP protocol].

Title: Linux 2.4 Kernel execve() Race Condition May Let Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user may be able to crash the system.
It is reported that a local user can exploit a file read race condition in the execve() system call to trigger a crash.

Paul Starzetz is credited with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A local user may be able to crash the system.
Solution: It is not clear if an upstream fix is available yet. Fixes for individual kernel distributions are pending. Check the Message History for fixes from various kernel vendors.

Title: Linux 2.4 Kernel /proc/tty/driver/serial May Disclose Password Characteristics to Local Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A flaw in '/proc/tty/driver/serial' may let local users gain information about password characteristics.
It is reported that '/proc/tty/driver/serial discloses the exact character counts for information on the serial links.  A local user can monitor this object to attempt to determine the length of a target user's password (as typed) and keystroke timing, which can yield information about the target user's password.
Impact': A local user may be able to obtain information about password lengths and password keystroke timing.
Solution: It is not clear if an upstream fix is available yet.  Fixes for individual kernel distributions are pending.  Check the Message History for fixes from various kernel vendors.

Title: Linux 2.4 Kernel Spanning Tree Protocol Bug Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel in the Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) implementation.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
It is reported that the STP implementation does not properly validate the length of user-supplied input.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.

It is also reported that a remote user can modify the bridge topology [due to the inherent insecurity of the STP protocol].
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
Solution: It is not clear if an upstream fix is available yet.  Fixes for individual kernel distributions are pending.  Check the Message History for fixes from various kernel vendors.

Title: KNOPPIX CD Default Configuration May Let Local Users Grab Root Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the default configuration of the KNOPPIX CD.  A local user can obtain root privileges.
It is reported that the "knx-hdinstall" default configuration creates unsafe temporary files in the '/tmp/.qt/' directory:  'qt_plugins_3.0rc', and 'qt_plugins_3.0rc.lock'.  A local user can create a symbolic link (symlink) from a critical file on the system to one of these temporary files.  Then, when a target user logs in, the symlinked file will be overwritten with the privileges of the target user, potentially including the root user.
Impact': A local user can cause a target user to overwrite a file on the system with the privileges of the target user.  This can be exploited by a local user to potentially obtain root privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix for Enterprise AS) Re: Linux Kernel ptrace() Flaw Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Description:

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix for Enterprise AS) Re: Linux 2.4 Kernel Route Cache Flaw Allows Remote Users to Cause Denial of Service Conditions
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 operating system kernel route cache hash table.  A remote user can send specially crafted packets to cause excessive CPU utilization and denial of service conditions.
It is reported that the kernel and the Netfilter IP conntrack module hash table implementations contain a flaw.  Other hash table implementations within the kernel may also be affected.  A remote user can send packets with specially crafted and invalid source addresses to cause hash collisions, with every routing cache entry hashed into the same hash chain.  This will cause the kernel to consume excessive CPU resources and can result in denial of service conditions.

According to the report, on a target host using 1 GB of RAM, a stream of 400 packets per second can cause the host to freeze.
Impact': A remote user can cause the kernel to freeze.
Solution:
Red Hat has issued a fix.  See the Source Message for the Red Hat advisory, which outlines important instructions regarding upgrading the kernel.

Title: User Mode Linux 'uml_net' Configuration Error Lets Local Users Perform Privileged Operations
Description:
In the original report (based on a Red Hat Errata), it was noted that there was a configuration vulnerability in the kernel-utils package in uml_net.  An updated report indicates that the upstream version of uml_net is still vulnerable and that a local user can execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
A local user can reportedly supply a large negative version number to cause uml_net to execute arbitrary code.  Because uml_net is configured with set user id (setuid) root user privileges, the code will run with root privileges.

[Editor's note:  The original Red Hat advisory RHSA-2003:056-08 did not mention the negative integer overflow vulnerability, instead indicating that the main problem with uml_net was that the utility was improperly configured with setuid root user privileges, and the solution appears to have been associated with removing the setuid status.  The related Red Hat bugzilla bug report #83685 submitted by Johnny Robertson accuractly mentioned the integer overflow flaw.  However, at the time of this entry, the vulnerability had not been corrected in the upstream uml_net distribution.  Credit goes to ktha@hushmail.com for noting the flaw in the upstream version and confirming that arbitrary code can indeed be executed.]
Impact': A local user can perform certain privileged networking operations.
Solution:
At the time of this entry, no solution was available from the upstream vendor.

For Red Hat users, Red Hat has issued a version that removes the suid configuration, mitigating the impact of the vulnerability [see the Message History for information on the Red Hat fix.]

Title: (Slackware Issues Revised Advisory) Slackware Linux Configuration Flaw in 'sysvinit' May Let Local Users Bypass Some Filesystem Access Restrictions
Description:
A configuration vulnerability was reported Slackware Linux in sysvinit.  A local user may be able to bypass certain filesystem access permissions (e.g., nosuid, nodev, noexec).
It is reported that the sysvinit quotacheck in /etc/rc.d/rc.M incorrectly uses the 'M' option instead of the 'm' option:

    echo "Checking filesystem quotas:  /sbin/quotacheck -avugM"
    /sbin/quotacheck -avugM

The use of the 'M' option reportedly causes the filesystem to be remounted.  As a result, mount flags such as nosuid, nodev, noexec, and others are reset.

The vendor credits Jem Berkes with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A local user may be able to bypass some filesystem restriction attributes.
Solution:
The vendor has released a revised advisory, as the original advisory contained a typographical error in the ChangeLog section.  The correct advisory is contained in the Source Message.

The vendor has released a fixed sysvinit package for Slackware 9.0, available at:

ftp://ftp.slackware.com/pub/slackware/slackware-9.0/patches/packages/sysvinit-2.84-i38 6-26.tgz

The MD5 signatures are:

966281dbd4e8cac23264021b9ad48f61 sysvinit-2.84-i386-26.tgz


To install, upgrade using upgradepkg (as root):

upgradepkg sysvinit-2.84-i386-26.tgz

Then, move the new version of rc.M into place with the following command, as rc.M is considered a config file and upgradepkg will not overwrite these config files by default:

mv /etc/rc.d/rc.M.new /etc/rc.d/rc.M

Title: Linux 2.4 Kernel Route Cache Flaw Allows Remote Users to Cause Denial of Service Conditions
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 operating system kernel route cache hash table.  A remote user can send specially crafted packets to cause excessive CPU utilization and denial of service conditions.
It is reported that the kernel and the Netfilter IP conntrack module hash table implementations contain a flaw.  Other hash table implementations within the kernel may also be affected.  A remote user can send packets with specially crafted and invalid source addresses to cause hash collisions, with every routing cache entry hashed into the same hash chain.  This will cause the kernel to consume excessive CPU resources and can result in denial of service conditions.

According to the report, on a target host using 1 GB of RAM, a stream of 400 packets per second can cause the host to freeze.
Impact': A remote user can cause the kernel to freeze.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (2.4.21-rc2), available at:

http://www.kernel.org/

Title: SCO (Caldera) OpenLinux Does Not Reject Certain TCP SYN Packets, Potentially Facilitating Remote Attacks
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in SCO (Caldera) OpenLinux.  The TCP stack does not discard TCP SYN packets that also have the FIN bit set.
SCO notes that the operating system should reject TCP packets with both the SYN and FIN bits set, as allowing packets of that nature may "significantly improve" the chance of an unauthorized firewall traversal.

The vendor indicates that this issue was publicly raised by Paul Starzetz in October 2002.
Impact': A remote user may have a greater chance of success attempting to traverse the firewall.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

Title: (EnGarde Issues Fix) Linux 2.2 Kernel Bug in /proc/pid/mem mmap() Interface May Let Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux operating system kernel (version 2.2.x) in the /proc/pid/mem interface.  A local user could cause the system to crash, requiring a manual reboot to return to normal operations.
RAZOR issued an advisory warning of a flaw in how the /proc/pid/mem mmap() function is validated.  According to the report, the /proc/pid/mem interface is used to allow an application to access the memory of another application and is useful in debugging processes, but contains a flaw.

A local user could invoke mmap() with the PROT_READ parameter to request read access to memory pages that are non-readable to the traced process.  Due to the flaw, the local user may be granted a memory map that is marked as readable.  Then, the local user can reportedly request the kernel to read this memory, causing the system to crash.

Some demonstration exploit code is provided in the Source Message.

According to the report, the 2.4.x kernel does not contain the functionality needed to exploit this flaw, and so is "not immediately vulnerable."
Impact': A local user could cause the system to hang.  A manual reboot may be required to return the system to normal operations.
Solution:
EnGarde has released a fix.  Users of the EnGarde Professional edition can use the Guardian Digital Secure Network to update their systems automatically.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux 2.2 Kernel Bug in /proc/pid/mem mmap() Interface May Let Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux operating system kernel (version 2.2.x) in the /proc/pid/mem interface.  A local user could cause the system to crash, requiring a manual reboot to return to normal operations.
RAZOR issued an advisory warning of a flaw in how the /proc/pid/mem mmap() function is validated.  According to the report, the /proc/pid/mem interface is used to allow an application to access the memory of another application and is useful in debugging processes, but contains a flaw.

A local user could invoke mmap() with the PROT_READ parameter to request read access to memory pages that are non-readable to the traced process.  Due to the flaw, the local user may be granted a memory map that is marked as readable.  Then, the local user can reportedly request the kernel to read this memory, causing the system to crash.

Some demonstration exploit code is provided in the Source Message.

According to the report, the 2.4.x kernel does not contain the functionality needed to exploit this flaw, and so is "not immediately vulnerable."
Impact': A local user could cause the system to hang.  A manual reboot may be required to return the system to normal operations.
Solution:
Red Hat has released a fix.

Title: (Trustix Issues Fix) Linux Kernel ptrace() Flaw Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.2 and 2.4 kernels.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the system.
According to the report, the vulnerable resides in the ptrace() function.  No details were summarized in the report.

The vendor indicates that the 2.5 kernel is not affected.

The vendor credits Andrzej Szombierski for reporting the flaw.
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges.
Solution:

  <URI:http://www.trustix.net/pub/Trustix/updates/>
  <URI:ftp://ftp.trustix.net/pub/Trustix/updates/>

Title: Linux Kernel ptrace() Flaw Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.2 and 2.4 kernels.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the system.
According to the report, the vulnerable resides in the ptrace() function.  No details were summarized in the report.

The vendor indicates that the 2.5 kernel is not affected.

The vendor credits Andrzej Szombierski for reporting the flaw.
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix for the 2.2 and 2.4 kernels.

For Linux 2.2, the vendor has released Linux 2.2.25.  A patch is also available to apply to most prior 2.2 kernel releases.

The vendor has released a patch for Linux 2.4.20/Linux 2.4.21pre, available in the Source Message.  This patch reportedly changes the PR_SET_DUMPABLE prctl.

Individual Linux distribution vendors are releasing fixes for their specific distributions.  Check the Message History for those updates.

Title: (SuSE Issues Fix) lprold 'lprm' Buffer Overflow May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): 7.1, 7.2, 7.3, SuSE eMail Server 3.1, SuSE eMail Server III, SuSE Firewall Adminhost VPN, SuSE Linux Admin-CD for Firewall, SuSE
Description:
A buffer overflow was reported in the lprm utility for OpenBSD and other operating systems (this utility is part of the 'lprold' package on SuSE Linux).  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
According to the report, a bounds check fix added to the program back in 1996 was ineffective.  A local user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed.

The code will run with the privileges of lprm.  In OpenBSD 3.1 and prior versions, lprm is configured with set user id (setuid) root privileges.  In OpenBSD 3.2, lprm is configured with setuid daemon privileges.

The report indicates that it is not known whether the flaw is exploitable in practice or not.

The vendor credtis Arne Woerner for reporting the flaw.
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution:
SuSE has released a fix.

Title: Red Hat Linux Kernel-Utils 'uml_net' Configuration Error Lets Local Users Perform Privileged Operations
Description:
A configuration vulnerability was reported in Red Hat's kernel-utils package.  A local user may be able to perform privileged networking operations.
It is reported that the User-Mode Linux uml_net binary is incorrectly configured with set user id (setuid) root privileges.

A local user can control certain network interfaces, add and remove arp entries and routes, and place interfaces in and out of promiscuous mode.

Red Hat credits Johnny Robertson for reporting this flaw.
Impact': A local user can perform certain privileged networking operations.
Solution:
Red Hat has issued the following fix for Red Hat Linux 8.0:

SRPMS:

ftp://updates.redhat.com/8.0/en/os/SRPMS/kernel-utils-2.4-8.28.src.rpm

i386:

ftp://updates.redhat.com/8.0/en/os/i386/kernel-utils-2.4-8.28.i386.rpm

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Linux Kernel 2.4 O_DIRECT Processing Flaw May Disclose File System Information to Local Users
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user may be able to read some information from the file system that the user is not authorized to read.
It is reported that there is a vulnerability in the O_DIRECT handling in Linux kernels 2.4.10 and later.  An information leak may allow a local user with write privileges to the file system to read information from the file system from previously deleted files.  The local user may also be able to corrupt the file system in a minor fashion that can reportedly be easily repaired by fsck.
Impact': A local user may be able to read portions of previously deleted files (belonging to other users) and may be able to cause minor file system corruption.
Solution:
Mandrake has released a fix for Mandrake Linux 9.0:

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux Kernel 2.4 O_DIRECT Processing Flaw May Disclose File System Information to Local Users
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user may be able to read some information from the file system that the user is not authorized to read.
It is reported that there is a vulnerability in the O_DIRECT handling in Linux kernels 2.4.10 and later.  An information leak may allow a local user with write privileges to the file system to read information from the file system from previously deleted files.  The local user may also be able to corrupt the file system in a minor fashion that can reportedly be easily repaired by fsck.
Impact': A local user may be able to read portions of previously deleted files (belonging to other users) and may be able to cause minor file system corruption.
Solution:
Red Hat reports that, in the default configuration, Red Hat Linux is not vulnerable because the ext3 file system does not support the O_DIRECT feature.  The default file system in Red Hat Linux 7.2 and later is ext3.  Of the kernels Red Hat has released, only the 2.4.18 kernels are reported to be affected.

Title: Linux Kernel 2.4 O_DIRECT Processing Flaw May Disclose File System Information to Local Users
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user may be able to read some information from the file system that the user is not authorized to read.
It is reported that there is a vulnerability in the O_DIRECT handling in Linux kernels 2.4.10 and later.  An information leak may allow a local user with write privileges to the file system to read information from the file system from previously deleted files.  The local user may also be able to corrupt the file system in a minor fashion that can reportedly be easily repaired by fsck.
Impact': A local user may be able to read portions of previously deleted files (belonging to other users) and may be able to cause minor file system corruption.
Solution:
Vendors of the various Linux distributions are releasing fixes.  See the Message History for Alerts covering individual vendor fixes.

According to MITRE, the 2.4.18 kernel is affected.

[At the time of this entry, it was not clear exactly which version of the kernel contains the fix.]

Title: Linux 2.2 Kernel Bug in /proc/pid/mem mmap() Interface May Let Local Users Crash the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux operating system kernel (version 2.2.x) in the /proc/pid/mem interface.  A local user could cause the system to crash, requiring a manual reboot to return to normal operations.
RAZOR issued an advisory warning of a flaw in how the /proc/pid/mem mmap() function is validated.  According to the report, the /proc/pid/mem interface is used to allow an application to access the memory of another application and is useful in debugging processes, but contains a flaw.

A local user could invoke mmap() with the PROT_READ parameter to request read access to memory pages that are non-readable to the traced process.  Due to the flaw, the local user may be granted a memory map that is marked as readable.  Then, the local user can reportedly request the kernel to read this memory, causing the system to crash.

Some demonstration exploit code is provided in the Source Message.

According to the report, the 2.4.x kernel does not contain the functionality needed to exploit this flaw, and so is "not immediately vulnerable."
Impact': A local user could cause the system to hang.  A manual reboot may be required to return the system to normal operations.
Solution:
It is reported that, due to implementation reliability issues, the vendor will drop /proc/pid/mem mmap() functionality in 2.2 kernels. Because of this, there will be no fix for the issue that preserves the functionality.

The upcoming 2.2.24 release will reportedly address this issue.

A patch to disable the functionality is provided in the Source Message and in the RAZOR advisory at:

http://razor.bindview.com/publish/advisories/adv_mmap.html

Please read the instructions and caveats if you consider using the patch.

Title: Linux Kernel Netfilter/IPTables Experimental Queueing Bug May Disclose Network Traffic to Local Users
Description:
An access control vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel Netfilter/IPTables firewall functions.  A local user may be able to read arbitrary network traffic in certain circumstances.
According to the report, a userspace process without NET_ADMIN privileges can re-use the process id (PID) of a previous privileged process and possibly receive a limited amount of network traffic.

This would reportedly only occur if no network traffic had been queued after the privileged process exited and the unprivileged process was established.  Also, the kernel module will only transmit a limited number of packets to the userspace process without acknowledgment, limited to the queue length (the default is 1024 packets).

If a system has Netfilter (or iptables) enabled and the ip_queue or ip6_queue experimental IP queuing modules are being used, the system may be vulnerable.
Impact': A local user may be able to read network packets under certain circumstances.
Solution: The vendor has issued a fix and recommends that you upgrade to the Linux kernel 2.4.20 (stable) or 2.5.32 (development).
