Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Re: Linux Kernel 'Netfilter' Firewall Software Has an IRC DCC Protocol Connection Tracker Bug That May Let Remote Users Access Protected Hosts in Certain Situations
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel 'netfilter' firewall software that may allow remote users to access protected hosts in certain situations, depending on the firewall rule set.
It is reported that the netfilter connection tracking helper module for the Internet Relay Chat (IRC) Direct Client-to-Client (DCC) protocol contains a flaw.  This module is designed to monitor outgoing DCC CHAT/SEND requests and issue 'conntrack expectations' about the pending inbound DCC connections.  According to the report, the conntrack expectation is less precise than it should be, causing unwanted ports for inbound connections to be opened on the firewall.

The conntrack expectation is reportedly described by a 5-tuple (layer 4 protocol, source ip, source port, destination ip, destination port) and a mask that indicates the parts of the tuple that must match for a new connection to be accepted.  An implementation bug apparently causes the mask to be too wide in specifying the destination IP address (allowing any destination IP instead of a specific one).  As a result, incoming connection requests are only matched on the destination port number and not the destination IP address. 

The vendor credits Jozsef Kadlecsik with discovering this bug.
Impact': The impact reportedly depends on the ruleset in effect on the firewall.  In some cases (with, for example, a permissive "-m state --state RELATED -j ACCEPT" rule), a remote user may be able to traverse the firewall on a single port number to any destination IP address behind the firewall as soon as a user on the inside of the firewall issues an outbound IRC DCC request specifying that port number.
Solution:
Mandrake has issued a fix.  MandrakeSoft encourages all users to upgrade their kernel as soon as possible to these new 2.2 and 2.4 kernels.

Mandrake notes that this update cannot be accomplished via MandrakeUpdate; it must be done on the console.  This prevents one from upgrading a kernel instead of installing a new kernel.  To upgrade, please ensure that you have first upgraded iptables, mkinitrd, and initscripts packages if they are applicable to your platform.  Use "rpm -ivh kernel_package" to install the new kernel.  Prior to rebooting, double-check your /etc/lilo.conf, /boot/grub/menu.lst, or /etc/yaboot.conf (PPC users only) to ensure that you are able to boot properly into both old and new kernels (this will allow you to boot into the old kernel if the new kernel does not work to your liking).

LILO users should execute "/sbin/lilo -v", GRUB users should execute "sh /boot/grun/install.sh", and PPC users must type "/sbin/ybin -v" to write the boot record in order to reboot into the new kernel if you made any changes to the respective boot configuration files.

New kernels for Mandrake Linux 8.1/IA64 will be available shortly.

For Mandrake 7.1, 7.2, Corporate Server, and Single Enterprise Firewall.

Title: Mandrake Linux OS Default Installation Uses Insecure File Permissions on User Directories
Description:
A default configuration vulnerability was reported in Mandrake Linux.  The default security setting configures user home directories with world readable permissions.
It is reported that the default Mandrake Security (msec) level is set at "Standard" (level 2).  According to the report, the documentation indicates that this level is appropriate for multi-user local use (see http://www.mandrakesecure.net/en/docs/msec.php).

This level reportedly sets the permissions for user directories under the '/home' directory to 755 (group and world readable).

A local user can read the files in another user's home directory.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user can read other user's files.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) Openwall Linux Kernel Patch 'lcall()' Bug Lets Local Users Kill Processes Belonging to Other Users
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Openwall Project's Linux kernel security patches.  A local user could kill processes without authorization.
It is reported that, on x86-specific Linux distributions with the Openwall kernel patch, a local user could abuse a binary compatibility interface (lcall) to kill processes belonging to other users, including including system processes.
Impact': A local user could kill processes belonging to other users, including including system processes.
Solution:
Conectiva has released a fix.  This fix was used in the kernel shipped with Conectiva Linux 8.

Title: Next Generation POSIX Threading (NGPT) Shared Memory Implementation May Allow Local Users to Deny Service on the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Next Generation POSIX Threading (NGPT) software for Linux.  A local user may be able to cause denial of service conditions for threaded processes.
It is reported that NGPT version 1.9.0 uses a filesystem entry for the shared memory rendevous point.  A local user could possibly deny service to threaded processes or perform file spoofing.

No further details were provided.
Impact': A local user could deny service to the system or perform file spoofing attacks.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (1.9.1), available at:

http://oss.software.ibm.com/developerworks/opensource/pthreads/index2.html

The new release now uses the POSIX shared memory operations shm_open() and shm_unlink().

Title: 'Autorun' Utility for Xandros Desktop Linux Beta Discloses a Portion of Any File to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the 'autorun' utility for the Xandros Desktop Linux system.  A local user may be able to view a small portion of text files on the system.
A local user can reportedly call 'autorun' with the '-c' command line switch and a filename as the next argument to be able to read the first line of the specified file.

A demonstration exploit is provided:

autorun -c /etc/shadow 

Because autorun is configured with set user id (suid) root privileges, a local user can read the first line of any file on the system.
Impact': A local user can view the first line of any text file on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has prepared a fix for Xandros Desktop Beta 2.  The fix should be available shortly.

[Editor's note:  The beta program appears to be closed, so this should only affect current beta users.]

Title: (Mandrake Issues Workaround) Linux Netfilter Firewall Has ICMP Address Translation Bug That Leaks Internal Address and Port Number Data to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Linux Netfilter firewall network address translation (NAT) code.  A remote user could determine the firewall's address translation mappings and discover the addresses and port numbers of internal hosts.
Cartel Security reported that there is a bug in the Linux kernel's 'netfilter' NAT implementation.  It is reported that when the first packet of a connection is processed by a netfilter NAT rule and the packet causes the netfilter host to reply with an ICMP error message, the address and port number parameters of the inner IP packet within the ICMP error message are not properly translated.  As a result, a remote user can discover which ports on a particular host are being translated by the firewall and the true destination address of the packet.

According to the report, the ICMP error packets that are returned to the originating host may also be dropped by stateful firewalls that may not recognize the related connection.
Impact': A remote user could determine the netfilter mapping relationships and can determine the destination addresses.
Solution:
The vendor has released a workaround and indicates that a fix is being prepared.

In the meantime, if you use the NAT capabilities of iptables, you can protect yourself by filtering out untracked local ICMP packets using the following iptables command:

   iptables -A OUTPUT -m state -p icmp --state INVALID -j DROP

All kernel patches from iptables < 1.2.6a are vulnerable.  All kernel versions from 2.4.4 and up to (at least) 2.4.19-pre6 use a vulnerable version.

As a result, a remote user can discover which ports on a particular host are being translated by the firewall and the true destination address of the packet.

According to the report, the ICMP error packets that are returned to the originating host may also be dropped by stateful firewalls that may not recognize the related connection.

A patch has been developed by the netfilter team, available at:

Title: Linux 'ld-linux.so.2' Dynamic Linker Allows Local Users to Execute Programs For Which They Do Not Have Execute Permissions
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 'ld-linux.so.2' dynamic linker.  A local user can use this to execute binaries for which they have read but not execute privileges.
It is reported that a local user can execute any binary for which they have read privileges using '/lib/ld-linux.so.2', even if the user does not have execute privileges for the binary.  The user must specify the full path, as in the following form:

/lib/ld-linux.so.2 ./read-but-not-execute-binary

This apparently also allows a local user to execute binaries that are on a 'noexec' partition.

Several users have written that this is not a vulnerability, but is the expected behavior of the function.  They indicate that you cannot prevent users from executing a program when still giving the user read privileges, as the user can copy the program to another directory and chmod +x the file to get execute privileges.
Impact':
A local user can execute binaries that the user does not have execute privileges for (if they have read privileges).

Several users have written that this is not a true vulnerability (see the Description section).
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (HP Issues Fix for Audit Daemon in HP Secure OS for Linux) 'zlib' Shared Compression Library Contains 'Double Free()' Buffer Overflow That Lets Remote Users Cause Programs Using zlib to Crash or Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the zlib shared library, a widely used library that provides in-memory compress and decompression functions.  A remote user could cause programs using this library to crash or to execute arbitrary code on the system.
It is reported that certain types of input will cause zlib to free the same area of memory twice (i.e., perform a "double free"), resulting in a buffer overflow condition when expanding compressed input. A remote user can cause programs that process untrusted user-supplied compressed input to crash or potentially execute arbitrary code on the system.

HP reports that the audit daemon in HP Secure OS for Linux is vulnerable because it uses the vulnerable version of zlib.

It is reported that Matthias Clasen <maclas@gmx.de> and Owen Taylor <otaylor@redhat.com> discovered this bug in zlib.
Impact': A remote user can cause affected programs that use zlib to process untrusted user-supplied compressed input to crash or potentially execute arbitrary code on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a patch:  HPTL_00016

Title: Linux Kernel 'd_path' Truncation Flaw May Allow a Local User to Cause a Privileged Process to Operate on an Arbitrary Directory Path
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux operating system kernel.  A local user may be able to trick a privileged process into thinking that it is operating with a different directory.
It is reported that the kernel d_path() function may return a truncated path name instead of an error value for long path names. This function is apparently called by the getcwd(2) system call and the do_proc_readlink() function.  User-space processes that implement these calls may receive incorrect information regarding directory paths.

It is reported that that the d_path kernel function resolves a string that is a concatenation of subsequent path components starting from the trailing path component into a 'dentry'. The concatenated path name is apparently stored in a fixed-length buffer of PAGE_SIZE bytes.  If a dentry points to a path that exceeds PAGE_SIZE - 1 characters length, leading path components are not written to the buffer and function instead returns truncated path without an error value, according to the report.

A local user may be able to cause a privileged process to interpret that the proper directory name is an arbitrary directory.

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user may be able to cause a privileged process to interpret that the proper directory name is an arbitrary directory.  The process may read or write to the wrong directory.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Openwall Linux Kernel Patch 'lcall()' Bug Lets Local Users Kill Processes Belonging to Other Users
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Openwall Project's Linux kernel security patches.  A local user could kill processes without authorization.
It is reported that, on x86-specific Linux distributions with the Openwall kernel patch, a local user could abuse a binary compatibility interface (lcall) to kill processes belonging to other users, including including system processes.
Impact': A local user could kill processes belonging to other users, including including system processes.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix (2.2.20-ow2), available at:

	http://www.openwall.com/linux/

Both Owl-current and Owl 0.1-stable have been updated to include this version of the patch.   The updated Owl-current ISO image will contain the patch when that image is released.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux Kernel 'Netfilter' Firewall Software Has an IRC DCC Protocol Connection Tracker Bug That May Let Remote Users Access Protected Hosts in Certain Situations
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel 'netfilter' firewall software that may allow remote users to access protected hosts in certain situations, depending on the firewall rule set.
It is reported that the netfilter connection tracking helper module for the Internet Relay Chat (IRC) Direct Client-to-Client (DCC) protocol contains a flaw.  This module is designed to monitor outgoing DCC CHAT/SEND requests and issue 'conntrack expectations' about the pending inbound DCC connections.  According to the report, the conntrack expectation is less precise than it should be, causing unwanted ports for inbound connections to be opened on the firewall.

The conntrack expectation is reportedly described by a 5-tuple (layer 4 protocol, source ip, source port, destination ip, destination port) and a mask that indicates the parts of the tuple that must match for a new connection to be accepted.  An implementation bug apparently causes the mask to be too wide in specifying the destination IP address (allowing any destination IP instead of a specific one).  As a result, incoming connection requests are only matched on the destination port number and not the destination IP address. 

The vendor credits Jozsef Kadlecsik with discovering this bug.
Impact': The impact reportedly depends on the ruleset in effect on the firewall.  In some cases (with, for example, a permissive "-m state --state RELATED -j ACCEPT" rule), a remote user may be able to traverse the firewall on a single port number to any destination IP address behind the firewall as soon as a user on the inside of the firewall issues an outbound IRC DCC request specifying that port number.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

Title: Linux Kernel 'Netfilter' Firewall Software Has an IRC DCC Protocol Connection Tracker Bug That May Let Remote Users Access Protected Hosts in Certain Situations
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel 'netfilter' firewall software that may allow remote users to access protected hosts in certain situations, depending on the firewall rule set.
It is reported that the netfilter connection tracking helper module for the Internet Relay Chat (IRC) Direct Client-to-Client (DCC) protocol contains a flaw.  This module is designed to monitor outgoing DCC CHAT/SEND requests and issue 'conntrack expectations' about the pending inbound DCC connections.  According to the report, the conntrack expectation is less precise than it should be, causing unwanted ports for inbound connections to be opened on the firewall.

The conntrack expectation is reportedly described by a 5-tuple (layer 4 protocol, source ip, source port, destination ip, destination port) and a mask that indicates the parts of the tuple that must match for a new connection to be accepted.  An implementation bug apparently causes the mask to be too wide in specifying the destination IP address (allowing any destination IP instead of a specific one).  As a result, incoming connection requests are only matched on the destination port number and not the destination IP address. 

The vendor credits Jozsef Kadlecsik with discovering this bug.
Impact': The impact reportedly depends on the ruleset in effect on the firewall.  In some cases (with, for example, a permissive "-m state --state RELATED -j ACCEPT" rule), a remote user may be able to traverse the firewall on a single port number to any destination IP address behind the firewall as soon as a user on the inside of the firewall issues an outbound IRC DCC request specifying that port number.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  Users can update to a >= 2.4.18-pre9 kernel or can apply a patch.  The patch is provided at the Vendor URL (and is contained in the Source Message).
Underlying OS Comments: All Linux kernel versions from 2.4.14 to 2.4.18-pre8

Title: Astaro Linux Insecure Default File Permissions May Allow a Local User to Gain Elevated Privileges on the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
iDEFENSE reported some vulnerabilities in Astaro Security Linux.  A local user could gain elevated privileges on the system or could deny service.
It is reported that several sensitive configuration files and directories are configured to be world writeable.  These include the following files:

  /etc/protocols 
  /etc/ssh/ssh_host_dsa_key.pub 
  /etc/ssh/ssh_host_key.pub
  /etc/up2date/latest_md5sum 
  /wtc/wfe/conf/console 
  /wtc/wfe/conf/nameserver 
  /wtc/wfe/conf/netzkartendata 
  /var/log/account/timestamp 

A local user may be able to modify some of these files to obtain elevated privileges on the server.  Specific exploit methods were not disclosed.

The product also reportedly includes the following world-writable directories:

  /var 
  /etc/up2date/lib1 
  /etc/up2date/lib2 

It is reported that a local user may be able to prevent log files from being written in the /var partition.
Impact': A local user may be able to modify files to gain elevated privileges on the system.  A local user may be able to create denial of service conditions on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  It is reported that the latest Up2Date 2.022 fixes the file permissions, which is now currently available on Astaro Up2Date servers:

http://www.astaro.org/cgi/ultimatebb.cgi?ubb=get_topic&f=1&t=000093

Title: (HP Indicates that No Fix is Available for HP Secure OS for Linux) Red Hat Linux 7.1 Korean Language Installation Program Umask Configuration Error Creates Files With the Wrong Permissions During Installation
Description:
Red Hat reported a configuration error in the Red Hat Linux 7.1 installation program.  Files may be created with the wrong permissions.
Red Hat reports that, due to the kernel used in the Red Hat Linux 7.1 Korean language installation program, some files are created by the installation program with the wrong permissions.  In this installation program, the 2.4.3-12 kernel sets the default umask for init to 000 and the installation program inherits this umask, causing files to be incorrectly written with world-writable permissions.
Impact': Files are incorrectly written with world-writable permissions during installation.
Solution: HP has warned that the Red Hat 7.1 Korean installation creates some files with incorrect permissions but indicates that there will be no applicable fix available for this problem (from HP).  The vendor states that "Hewlett-Packard Company does not support a Korean version of HP Secure OS Software for Linux Release 1.0."
Underlying OS Comments: Only affects Red Hat 7.1 Linux Korean language installations

Title: (HP Issues Fix for HP Secure OS for Linux) Linux Kernel Ptrace Flaw Lets Local Users Obtain Root Level Privileges on the Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): HP Secure OS software for Linux Release 1.0
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Linux kernel ptrace function.  A local user can execute arbitrary commands with root level privileges, gaining root level access on the host.
Ptrace can be used by a non-privileged local user to attach a suid binary as a tracing process, where the set user id (suid) bit of the attached child will be honored, allowing the local user to execute commands with suid root privileges.

The following steps can be used to trigger the vulnerability.  A non-privileged parent process uses ptrace() to attach a non-privileged child process.  The parent process executes a suid function (such as newgrp) and then the child process follows with an execve() call to any suid function.  It is reported that the property of "having an ptrace-attached child" survives the execve() call.  Because the parent process (i.e., the tracer process) has root privileges at this point (via the suid bit), it can trace the child process.  Then, the parent process executes a shell, which is still able to control the child process with ptrace.  This shell can insert arbitrary code into the address space of the child process, where the code will be executed with root privileges (via the child's suid status).

For a local user to exploit this vulnerability, a suid root binary that will exec a user-defined binary (or shell) is required.  For example, the kernel flaw can be exploited using the newgrp() function.  It is reported that the following conditions must be met for this to be exploitable:

1) /usr/bin/newgrp must be suid root
2) /usr/bin/newgrp must be world-executable
3) /usr/bin/newgrp should not prompt for password when run with no arguments.

It is reported that these conditions are are satisfied by most of the popular Linux distributions.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Sourc Message.
Impact': A local user can execute commands with root level privileges, giving the local user root level access on the host.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix for HP Secure OS for Linux 1.0.  Apply one of the following patches (depending upon the processor architecture on the installed system):

                  Architecture,    Patch ID
                  i586,            HPTL_00004
                  i686-UNP,        HPTL_00005
                  i686-SMP,        HPTL_00006

The patches are available at http://itrc.hp.com

Title: (HP Issues Fix for HP Secure OS for Linux) Linux Kernel TCP Syn Cookies Flaw Lets Remote Users Bypass Certain Firewall Rules to Access Protected Ports on the Server in Limited Cases
Version(s): HP Secure OS software for Linux Release 1.0
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux Kernel's firewalling of SYN packets when kernel syn cookie support is enabled.  A remote user could access protected ports in certain limited cases.
It is reported that if syn cookies are enabled and being sent by the kernel (as would happen during a TCP SYN flood attack, for example), a remote user may be able to connect to certain firewalled ports that are protected by firewall rules filtering SYN packets.

Because of the syn cookies, the remote user is not required to send SYN packets to initiate the connection, only ACK packets are needed but with the restriction that the magic cookie is correct.  A remote user can attempt to brute force guess the correct magic cookie by exploring approximately 16 million values (2^24).  This can apparently be achieved within a few hours time against a server with a fast network connection.

This flaw was reportedly discovered by Manfred Spraul and patched by Andi Kleen from SuSE.
Impact': If syn cookies are enabled and being sent, a remote user can attempt to guess a valid magic cookie and connect to a protected (firewalled) port.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix for HP Secure OS for Linux.  Apply one of the following patches (depending upon the processor architecture on the installed system):

                  Architecture,    Patch ID
                  i586,            HPTL_00004
                  i686-UNP,        HPTL_00005
                  i686-SMP,        HPTL_00006

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Linux Kernel devfs Race Condition Lets Local Users Gain Root Level Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Linux kernel devfs implementation.  A race condition allows local users to obtain root level privileges.
The vulnerability is reportedly due to a race condition in devfs/base.c.  No further details were provided.

This flaw was reportedly discovered by Alexander Viro.
Impact': A local user could obtain root level privileges on the host.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  The vendor notes that this update is *not* meant to be done via MandrakeUpdate!  You must download the necessary RPMs and upgrade manually by following these steps:

   1.  Type: rpm -ivh kernel-[version].i586.rpm
   2.  Type: mv kernel-[version].i586.rpm /tmp
   3.  Type: rpm -Fvh *.rpm
   4a. You may wish to edit /etc/lilo.conf to ensure a new entry is in
       place.  The new kernel will be the last entry.  Change any options
       you need to change.  You will also want to create a new entry with
       the initrd and image directives pointing to the old kernel's
       vmlinuz and initrd images so you may also boot from the old
       images if required.
   4b. PPC users must execute some additional instructions.  First edit
       /etc/yaboot.conf and add a new entry for the kernel and change
       any options that you need to change.  You must also create a new
       initrd image to enable USB support for keyboards and mice by
       typing: 
         mkinitrd --with=usb-ohci /boot/initrd-2.4.8-31.3mdk 2.4.8-31.3mdk
   5a. If you use lilo, type: /sbin/lilo -v
   5b. If you use GRUB, type: sh /boot/grub/install.sh
  5c. PPC users must type: /sbin/ybin -v

You may then reboot and use the new kernel and remove the older kernel when you are comfortable using the upgraded one.

Title: (Issue Has Been Fixed) Re: Linux 2.4 Kernel Denial of Service Condition Allows Non-privileged Local Users to Reboot the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in certain versions of the Linux 2.4 kernel.  A local user may be able to cause the system to reboot.
A local user can start the file /usr/src/linux/vmlinux to cause the system to crash.  Ordinarily, starting this file should exit with SIGSEGV instead of crashing.
Impact': A local user can cause the system to reboot.
Solution:
It is reported that the bug has been fixed in kernel version 2.4.11pre3.  A patch to fix vanilla 2.4.10 can be downloaded from here:

ftp://ftp.us.kernel.org/pub/linux/kernel/people/andrea/patches/v2.4/2.4.10/binfmt_elf-checks-1

A patch to fix the 2.4.10.SuSE-7.3 kernel (both the original one in the CDs, and also the first kernel security update) can be downloaded from here:

Title: (Mandrake Issues Revised Fix for 2.4 Kernel) Linux Kernel Ptrace Flaw Lets Local Users Obtain Root Level Privileges on the Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Linux kernel ptrace function.  A local user can execute arbitrary commands with root level privileges, gaining root level access on the host.
Ptrace can be used by a non-privileged local user to attach a suid binary as a tracing process, where the set user id (suid) bit of the attached child will be honored, allowing the local user to execute commands with suid root privileges.

The following steps can be used to trigger the vulnerability.  A non-privileged parent process uses ptrace() to attach a non-privileged child process.  The parent process executes a suid function (such as newgrp) and then the child process follows with an execve() call to any suid function.  It is reported that the property of "having an ptrace-attached child" survives the execve() call.  Because the parent process (i.e., the tracer process) has root privileges at this point (via the suid bit), it can trace the child process.  Then, the parent process executes a shell, which is still able to control the child process with ptrace.  This shell can insert arbitrary code into the address space of the child process, where the code will be executed with root privileges (via the child's suid status).

For a local user to exploit this vulnerability, a suid root binary that will exec a user-defined binary (or shell) is required.  For example, the kernel flaw can be exploited using the newgrp() function.  It is reported that the following conditions must be met for this to be exploitable:

1) /usr/bin/newgrp must be suid root
2) /usr/bin/newgrp must be world-executable
3) /usr/bin/newgrp should not prompt for password when run with no arguments.

It is reported that these conditions are are satisfied by most of the popular Linux distributions.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Sourc Message.
Impact': A local user can execute commands with root level privileges, giving the local user root level access on the host.
Solution:
The vendor has released a revised fix for the 2.4 kernel.  The vendor notes that this update is *not* meant to be done via MandrakeUpdate! Instead, download the necessary RPMs and upgrade manually by following these steps:

   1.  Type: rpm -ivh kernel-[version].i586.rpm
  2.  Type: mv kernel-[version].i586.rpm /tmp
   3.  Type: rpm -Fvh *.rpm
   4a. You may wish to edit /etc/lilo.conf to ensure a new entry is in
       place.  The new kernel will be the last entry.  Change any options
       you need to change.  You will also want to create a new entry with
       the initrd and image directives pointing to the old kernel's
       vmlinuz and initrd images so you may also boot from the old
       images if required.
   4b. PPC users must execute some additional instructions.  First edit
       /etc/yaboot.conf and add a new entry for the kernel and change
       any options that you need to change.  You must also create a new
       initrd image to enable USB support for keyboards and mice by
       typing: 
         mkinitrd --with=usb-ohci /boot/initrd-2.4.8-31.3mdk 2.4.8-31.3mdk
   5a. If you use lilo, type: /sbin/lilo -v
   5b. If you use GRUB, type: sh /boot/grub/install.sh
   5c. PPC users must type: /sbin/ybin -v

You may then reboot and use the new kernel and remove the older kernel when you are comfortable using the upgraded one.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Revised Fix for 2.4 Kernel) Linux Kernel Nested Symlink Dereferencing Flaw Lets Local Users Deny Service to Other Processes on the Host
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A local denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel.  A local user can create deeply nested symbolic links that will force the kernel to consume processing cycles attempting to dereference the symlink, preventing other processes from running.
A local user can create a deeply nested series of symlinks.  Then, when the user issues the Linux command 'head' on the file name, the kernel will reportedly block the scheduler while attempting to dereference the file name.  As a result, other processes will be prevented from running for up to several hours or more, depending on the depth of nesting.

It is reported that in kernel version 2.4.10 partially fixed this problem, preventing the scheduler from being blocked but not permitting the rogue process to be killed.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can cause a process to consume all processing resources and prevent other processes from running.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Revised Fix for 2.2 Kernel) Linux Kernel Nested Symlink Dereferencing Flaw Lets Local Users Deny Service to Other Processes on the Host
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A local denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel.  A local user can create deeply nested symbolic links that will force the kernel to consume processing cycles attempting to dereference the symlink, preventing other processes from running.
A local user can create a deeply nested series of symlinks.  Then, when the user issues the Linux command 'head' on the file name, the kernel will reportedly block the scheduler while attempting to dereference the file name.  As a result, other processes will be prevented from running for up to several hours or more, depending on the depth of nesting.

It is reported that in kernel version 2.4.10 partially fixed this problem, preventing the scheduler from being blocked but not permitting the rogue process to be killed.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can cause a process to consume all processing resources and prevent other processes from running.
Solution:
The vendor has released a revised fix for the 2.2 kernel.  This also includes a fix for the TCP SYN cookie flaw, described in a separate alert.  The vendor notes that this update is *not* meant to be done via MandrakeUpdate.  Instead, download the necessary RPMs and upgrade manually by following these steps:

   1.  Type: rpm -ivh kernel-[version].i586.rpm
   2.  Type: mv kernel-[version].i586.rpm /tmp
   3.  Type: rpm -Fvh *.rpm
   4a. You may wish to edit /etc/lilo.conf to ensure a new entry is in
       place.  The new kernel will be the last entry.  Change any options
       you need to change.  You will also want to create a new entry with
       the initrd and image directives pointing to the old kernel's
       vmlinuz and initrd images so you may also boot from the old
       images if required.
   4b. PPC users must execute some additional instructions.  First edit
       /etc/yaboot.conf and add a new entry for the kernel and change
       any options that you need to change.  You must also create a new
       initrd image to enable USB support for keyboards and mice by
       typing: 
         mkinitrd --with=usb-ohci /boot/initrd-2.2.19-20.1mdk 2.2.19-20.1mdk
   5a. If you use lilo, type: /sbin/lilo -v
   5b. If you use GRUB, type: sh /boot/grub/install.sh
   5c. PPC users must type: /sbin/ybin -v

You may then reboot and use the new kernel and remove the older kernel when you are comfortable using the upgraded one.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Linux Kernel TCP Syn Cookies Flaw Lets Remote Users Bypass Certain Firewall Rules to Access Protected Ports on the Server in Limited Cases
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux Kernel's firewalling of SYN packets when kernel syn cookie support is enabled.  A remote user could access protected ports in certain limited cases.
It is reported that if syn cookies are enabled and being sent by the kernel (as would happen during a TCP SYN flood attack, for example), a remote user may be able to connect to certain firewalled ports that are protected by firewall rules filtering SYN packets.

Because of the syn cookies, the remote user is not required to send SYN packets to initiate the connection, only ACK packets are needed but with the restriction that the magic cookie is correct.  A remote user can attempt to brute force guess the correct magic cookie by exploring approximately 16 million values (2^24).  This can apparently be achieved within a few hours time against a server with a fast network connection.

This flaw was reportedly discovered by Manfred Spraul and patched by Andi Kleen from SuSE.
Impact': If syn cookies are enabled and being sent, a remote user can attempt to guess a valid magic cookie and connect to a protected (firewalled) port.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  The vendor notes that this update is *not* meant to be done via MandrakeUpdate.  Instead, download the necessary RPMs and upgrade manually by following these steps:

   1.  Type: rpm -ivh kernel-[version].i586.rpm
   2.  Type: mv kernel-[version].i586.rpm /tmp
   3.  Type: rpm -Fvh *.rpm
   4a. You may wish to edit /etc/lilo.conf to ensure a new entry is in
       place.  The new kernel will be the last entry.  Change any options
       you need to change.  You will also want to create a new entry with
       the initrd and image directives pointing to the old kernel's
       vmlinuz and initrd images so you may also boot from the old
       images if required.
   4b. PPC users must execute some additional instructions.  First edit
       /etc/yaboot.conf and add a new entry for the kernel and change
       any options that you need to change.  You must also create a new
       initrd image to enable USB support for keyboards and mice by
       typing: 
         mkinitrd --with=usb-ohci /boot/initrd-2.2.19-20.1mdk 2.2.19-20.1mdk
   5a. If you use lilo, type: /sbin/lilo -v
   5b. If you use GRUB, type: sh /boot/grub/install.sh
   5c. PPC users must type: /sbin/ybin -v

Title: Red Hat Linux 7.1 Korean Language Installation Program Umask Configuration Error Creates Files With the Wrong Permissions During Installation
Description:
Red Hat reported a configuration error in the Red Hat Linux 7.1 installation program.  Files may be created with the wrong permissions.
Red Hat reports that, due to the kernel used in the Red Hat Linux 7.1 Korean language installation program, some files are created by the installation program with the wrong permissions.  In this installation program, the 2.4.3-12 kernel sets the default umask for init to 000 and the installation program inherits this umask, causing files to be incorrectly written with world-writable permissions.
Impact': Files are incorrectly written with world-writable permissions during installation.
Solution:
The vendor recommends that all users of the Red Hat Linux 7.1 Korean installation program use the updated disk image.  If a user has already installed the kernel, the vendor recommends that they check their systems and fix the permissions on the affected files. This can be done by installing the updated redhat-release package.

If you have not installed:
--------------------------

Download the update disk image and create an update disk. This can be done by using the same procedure used to create a boot diskette.

For more information, see:

http://www.redhat.com/docs/manuals/linux/RHL-7.1-Manual/install-guide/s1-steps-install-cdrom.html#S2-STEPS-MAKE-DISKS

Please note that you must substitute the update disk image filename for the filename used in the example.

When booting into the installation program, type "linux updates" at the boot prompt, followed by any other installation options (such as "expert" or "text" or "ks"). The installation process will prompt you to insert the update disk when it is required, and the installation will then proceed as normal.

If you have already installed:
------------------------------
Check the permissions on the affected files and change them as appropriate.  Or install the upgraded redhat-release; this will change the the permissions during its postinstall phase.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix) Linux 2.4 Kernel Netfilter iptables Firewall Software May Fail to Properly Drop Some Packets
Description:
A security hole was reported in the Linux Netfilter iptables firewall software.  Remote users may be able to pass packets through the firewall in certain situations.
The flaw resides in the MAC module, which is designed to match packets based on their Ethernet MAC address.  It is reported that the MAC module does not correctly match very small packets.  If MAC matching/filtering is used, a remote user may be able to pass small packets through the firewall.
Impact': A remote user may be able to pass small packets through the firewall if MAC address matching is used in the rule set.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

Title: (Caldera Issues Fix for OpenLinux) Linux Kernel TCP Syn Cookies Flaw Lets Remote Users Bypass Certain Firewall Rules to Access Protected Ports on the Server in Limited Cases
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux Kernel's firewalling of SYN packets when kernel syn cookie support is enabled.  A remote user could access protected ports in certain limited cases.
It is reported that if syn cookies are enabled and being sent by the kernel (as would happen during a TCP SYN flood attack, for example), a remote user may be able to connect to certain firewalled ports that are protected by firewall rules filtering SYN packets.

Because of the syn cookies, the remote user is not required to send SYN packets to initiate the connection, only ACK packets are needed but with the restriction that the magic cookie is correct.  A remote user can attempt to brute force guess the correct magic cookie by exploring approximately 16 million values (2^24).  This can apparently be achieved within a few hours time against a server with a fast network connection.

This flaw was reportedly discovered by Manfred Spraul and patched by Andi Kleen from SuSE.
Impact': If syn cookies are enabled and being sent, a remote user can attempt to guess a valid magic cookie and connect to a protected (firewalled) port.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  The following packages are affected:

OpenLinux 2.3, all packages previous to linux-2.2.10-14; OpenLinux eServer 2.3.1 and eBuilder, all packages previous to linux-2.2.14-13S; OpenLinux eDesktop 2.4, all packages previous to linux-2.2.14-9; OpenLinux Server 3.1, all packages previous to linux-2.4.2-14S; OpenLinux Workstation 3.1, all packages previous to linux-2.4.2-14D.

Title: (Engarde Issues Fix) Linux Kernel TCP Syn Cookies Flaw Lets Remote Users Bypass Certain Firewall Rules to Access Protected Ports on the Server in Limited Cases
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux Kernel's firewalling of SYN packets when kernel syn cookie support is enabled.  A remote user could access protected ports in certain limited cases.
It is reported that if syn cookies are enabled and being sent by the kernel (as would happen during a TCP SYN flood attack, for example), a remote user may be able to connect to certain firewalled ports that are protected by firewall rules filtering SYN packets.

Because of the syn cookies, the remote user is not required to send SYN packets to initiate the connection, only ACK packets are needed but with the restriction that the magic cookie is correct.  A remote user can attempt to brute force guess the correct magic cookie by exploring approximately 16 million values (2^24).  This can apparently be achieved within a few hours time against a server with a fast network connection.

This flaw was reportedly discovered by Manfred Spraul and patched by Andi Kleen from SuSE.
Impact': If syn cookies are enabled and being sent, a remote user can attempt to guess a valid magic cookie and connect to a protected (firewalled) port.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Nested Symlink Dereferencing Flaw Lets Local Users Deny Service to Other Processes on the Host
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A local denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel.  A local user can create deeply nested symbolic links that will force the kernel to consume processing cycles attempting to dereference the symlink, preventing other processes from running.
A local user can create a deeply nested series of symlinks.  Then, when the user issues the Linux command 'head' on the file name, the kernel will reportedly block the scheduler while attempting to dereference the file name.  As a result, other processes will be prevented from running for up to several hours or more, depending on the depth of nesting.

It is reported that in kernel version 2.4.10 partially fixed this problem, preventing the scheduler from being blocked but not permitting the rogue process to be killed.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can cause a process to consume all processing resources and prevent other processes from running.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Ptrace Flaw Lets Local Users Obtain Root Level Privileges on the Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Linux kernel ptrace function.  A local user can execute arbitrary commands with root level privileges, gaining root level access on the host.
Ptrace can be used by a non-privileged local user to attach a suid binary as a tracing process, where the set user id (suid) bit of the attached child will be honored, allowing the local user to execute commands with suid root privileges.

The following steps can be used to trigger the vulnerability.  A non-privileged parent process uses ptrace() to attach a non-privileged child process.  The parent process executes a suid function (such as newgrp) and then the child process follows with an execve() call to any suid function.  It is reported that the property of "having an ptrace-attached child" survives the execve() call.  Because the parent process (i.e., the tracer process) has root privileges at this point (via the suid bit), it can trace the child process.  Then, the parent process executes a shell, which is still able to control the child process with ptrace.  This shell can insert arbitrary code into the address space of the child process, where the code will be executed with root privileges (via the child's suid status).

For a local user to exploit this vulnerability, a suid root binary that will exec a user-defined binary (or shell) is required.  For example, the kernel flaw can be exploited using the newgrp() function.  It is reported that the following conditions must be met for this to be exploitable:

1) /usr/bin/newgrp must be suid root
2) /usr/bin/newgrp must be world-executable
3) /usr/bin/newgrp should not prompt for password when run with no arguments.

It is reported that these conditions are are satisfied by most of the popular Linux distributions.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Sourc Message.
Impact': A local user can execute commands with root level privileges, giving the local user root level access on the host.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Nested Symlink Dereferencing Flaw Lets Local Users Deny Service to Other Processes on the Host
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A local denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel.  A local user can create deeply nested symbolic links that will force the kernel to consume processing cycles attempting to dereference the symlink, preventing other processes from running.
A local user can create a deeply nested series of symlinks.  Then, when the user issues the Linux command 'head' on the file name, the kernel will reportedly block the scheduler while attempting to dereference the file name.  As a result, other processes will be prevented from running for up to several hours or more, depending on the depth of nesting.

It is reported that in kernel version 2.4.10 partially fixed this problem, preventing the scheduler from being blocked but not permitting the rogue process to be killed.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can cause a process to consume all processing resources and prevent other processes from running.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  The vendor notes that this update should be performed manually by following these steps:

   1.  Type: rpm -ivh kernel-[version].i586.rpm
   2.  Type: mv kernel-[version].i586.rpm /tmp
   3.  Type: rpm -Fvh *.rpm
   4a. You may wish to edit /etc/lilo.conf to ensure a new entry is in
       place.  The new kernel will be the last entry.  Change any options
       you need to change.  You will also want to create a new entry with
       the initrd and image directives pointing to the old kernel's
       vmlinuz and initrd images so you may also boot from the old
       images if required.
   4b. PPC users must execute some additional instructions.  First edit
       /etc/yaboot.conf and add a new entry for the kernel and change
       any options that you need to change.  You must also create a new
       initrd image to enable USB support for keyboards and mice by
       typing: 
         mkinitrd --with=usb-ohci /boot/initrd-2.2.19-19.1mdk 2.2.19-19.1mdk
   5a. Type: /sbin/lilo -v
   5b. PPC users must type: /sbin/ybin -v

Title: (SuSE Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Nested Symlink Dereferencing Flaw Lets Local Users Deny Service to Other Processes on the Host
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A local denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel.  A local user can create deeply nested symbolic links that will force the kernel to consume processing cycles attempting to dereference the symlink, preventing other processes from running.
A local user can create a deeply nested series of symlinks.  Then, when the user issues the Linux command 'head' on the file name, the kernel will reportedly block the scheduler while attempting to dereference the file name.  As a result, other processes will be prevented from running for up to several hours or more, depending on the depth of nesting.

It is reported that in kernel version 2.4.10 partially fixed this problem, preventing the scheduler from being blocked but not permitting the rogue process to be killed.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can cause a process to consume all processing resources and prevent other processes from running.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix for SuSE Linux.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.  In the vendor's advisory, thirteen steps are provided to help customers apply the proper upgrade.

Title: (SuSE Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Ptrace Flaw Lets Local Users Obtain Root Level Privileges on the Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Linux kernel ptrace function.  A local user can execute arbitrary commands with root level privileges, gaining root level access on the host.
Ptrace can be used by a non-privileged local user to attach a suid binary as a tracing process, where the set user id (suid) bit of the attached child will be honored, allowing the local user to execute commands with suid root privileges.

The following steps can be used to trigger the vulnerability.  A non-privileged parent process uses ptrace() to attach a non-privileged child process.  The parent process executes a suid function (such as newgrp) and then the child process follows with an execve() call to any suid function.  It is reported that the property of "having an ptrace-attached child" survives the execve() call.  Because the parent process (i.e., the tracer process) has root privileges at this point (via the suid bit), it can trace the child process.  Then, the parent process executes a shell, which is still able to control the child process with ptrace.  This shell can insert arbitrary code into the address space of the child process, where the code will be executed with root privileges (via the child's suid status).

For a local user to exploit this vulnerability, a suid root binary that will exec a user-defined binary (or shell) is required.  For example, the kernel flaw can be exploited using the newgrp() function.  It is reported that the following conditions must be met for this to be exploitable:

1) /usr/bin/newgrp must be suid root
2) /usr/bin/newgrp must be world-executable
3) /usr/bin/newgrp should not prompt for password when run with no arguments.

It is reported that these conditions are are satisfied by most of the popular Linux distributions.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Sourc Message.
Impact': A local user can execute commands with root level privileges, giving the local user root level access on the host.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix for SuSE Linux.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.  In the vendor's advisory, thirteen steps are provided to help customers apply the proper upgrade.

Title: Linux Kernel Quota Flaw Lets Local Users Exceed Quota Limits and Create Large Files
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel that allows local users to create files of a size in excess of their quota limits.
It is reported that this vulnerability can be exploited by a local user via almost any set user id (suid) root binary to create large files overriding the user's quota limits.

When a suid root binary inherits file descriptors from a user process, the binary may write to the file without respecting the quota restrictions.  This reportedly occurs because the suid process has CAP_SYS_RESOURCE effective capability enabled when writing to the file and Quota only checks the privileges of the current (suid) process rather than those of the user that opened the file descriptor.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

cliph$quota -u wp
Disk quotas for user wp (uid 500):
     Filesystem  blocks   quota   limit   files   quota   limit
      /dev/hda6       4      10      10       1      10      10

cliph$perl -e 'print "a"x16384' >>myfile
/vol1: write failed, user disk limit reached.

cliph$ls -l myfile
-rw-rw-r--    1 wp       wp           4096 Oct 22 10:33 myfile

cliph$su $(perl -e 'print "a"x16384') 2>>myfile
cliph$ # ^^^ this is it: su writes error message to fd 2 without limits

cliph$ls -l myfile
-rw-rw-r--    1 wp       wp          20505 Oct 22 10:34 myfile

cliph$quota -u wp
Disk quotas for user wp (uid 500):
     Filesystem  blocks   quota   limit   files   quota   limit
      /dev/hda6      28*     10      10       2      10      10
Impact': A local user can create files of a size that is larger than their quota limits allow.  A local user could deny service to other users by consuming excessive disk space.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Caldera Issues Fix) Linux 2.4 Kernel Netfilter iptables Firewall Software May Fail to Properly Drop Some Packets
Description:
A security hole was reported in the Linux Netfilter iptables firewall software.  Remote users may be able to pass packets through the firewall in certain situations.
The flaw resides in the MAC module, which is designed to match packets based on their Ethernet MAC address.  It is reported that the MAC module does not correctly match very small packets.  If MAC matching/filtering is used, a remote user may be able to pass small packets through the firewall.
Impact': A remote user may be able to pass small packets through the firewall if MAC address matching is used in the rule set.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: (Caldera Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Nested Symlink Dereferencing Flaw Lets Local Users Deny Service to Other Processes on the Host
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A local denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel.  A local user can create deeply nested symbolic links that will force the kernel to consume processing cycles attempting to dereference the symlink, preventing other processes from running.
A local user can create a deeply nested series of symlinks.  Then, when the user issues the Linux command 'head' on the file name, the kernel will reportedly block the scheduler while attempting to dereference the file name.  As a result, other processes will be prevented from running for up to several hours or more, depending on the depth of nesting.

It is reported that in kernel version 2.4.10 partially fixed this problem, preventing the scheduler from being blocked but not permitting the rogue process to be killed.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can cause a process to consume all processing resources and prevent other processes from running.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: (Caldera Issues Fix) Linux Kernel Ptrace Flaw Lets Local Users Obtain Root Level Privileges on the Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Linux kernel ptrace function.  A local user can execute arbitrary commands with root level privileges, gaining root level access on the host.
Ptrace can be used by a non-privileged local user to attach a suid binary as a tracing process, where the set user id (suid) bit of the attached child will be honored, allowing the local user to execute commands with suid root privileges.

The following steps can be used to trigger the vulnerability.  A non-privileged parent process uses ptrace() to attach a non-privileged child process.  The parent process executes a suid function (such as newgrp) and then the child process follows with an execve() call to any suid function.  It is reported that the property of "having an ptrace-attached child" survives the execve() call.  Because the parent process (i.e., the tracer process) has root privileges at this point (via the suid bit), it can trace the child process.  Then, the parent process executes a shell, which is still able to control the child process with ptrace.  This shell can insert arbitrary code into the address space of the child process, where the code will be executed with root privileges (via the child's suid status).

For a local user to exploit this vulnerability, a suid root binary that will exec a user-defined binary (or shell) is required.  For example, the kernel flaw can be exploited using the newgrp() function.  It is reported that the following conditions must be met for this to be exploitable:

1) /usr/bin/newgrp must be suid root
2) /usr/bin/newgrp must be world-executable
3) /usr/bin/newgrp should not prompt for password when run with no arguments.

It is reported that these conditions are are satisfied by most of the popular Linux distributions.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Sourc Message.
Impact': A local user can execute commands with root level privileges, giving the local user root level access on the host.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: (Red Hat Issues Fix for 2.4 Kernel) Linux Kernel Ptrace Flaw Lets Local Users Obtain Root Level Privileges on the Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Linux kernel ptrace function.  A local user can execute arbitrary commands with root level privileges, gaining root level access on the host.
Ptrace can be used by a non-privileged local user to attach a suid binary as a tracing process, where the set user id (suid) bit of the attached child will be honored, allowing the local user to execute commands with suid root privileges.

The following steps can be used to trigger the vulnerability.  A non-privileged parent process uses ptrace() to attach a non-privileged child process.  The parent process executes a suid function (such as newgrp) and then the child process follows with an execve() call to any suid function.  It is reported that the property of "having an ptrace-attached child" survives the execve() call.  Because the parent process (i.e., the tracer process) has root privileges at this point (via the suid bit), it can trace the child process.  Then, the parent process executes a shell, which is still able to control the child process with ptrace.  This shell can insert arbitrary code into the address space of the child process, where the code will be executed with root privileges (via the child's suid status).

For a local user to exploit this vulnerability, a suid root binary that will exec a user-defined binary (or shell) is required.  For example, the kernel flaw can be exploited using the newgrp() function.  It is reported that the following conditions must be met for this to be exploitable:

1) /usr/bin/newgrp must be suid root
2) /usr/bin/newgrp must be world-executable
3) /usr/bin/newgrp should not prompt for password when run with no arguments.

It is reported that these conditions are are satisfied by most of the popular Linux distributions.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Sourc Message.
Impact': A local user can execute commands with root level privileges, giving the local user root level access on the host.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix for the 2.4 Kernel.  See the separate alert for the 2.2 Kernel fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: Linux Kernel Nested Symlink Dereferencing Flaw Lets Local Users Deny Service to Other Processes on the Host
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A local denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Linux kernel.  A local user can create deeply nested symbolic links that will force the kernel to consume processing cycles attempting to dereference the symlink, preventing other processes from running.
A local user can create a deeply nested series of symlinks.  Then, when the user issues the Linux command 'head' on the file name, the kernel will reportedly block the scheduler while attempting to dereference the file name.  As a result, other processes will be prevented from running for up to several hours or more, depending on the depth of nesting.

It is reported that in kernel version 2.4.10 partially fixed this problem, preventing the scheduler from being blocked but not permitting the rogue process to be killed.

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can cause a process to consume all processing resources and prevent other processes from running.
Solution: It is reported that the 2.4.12 kernel fixes the denial of service issue.  A patch for 2.2.19 is available (see the file 2.2.19-deep-symlink.patch in the Source Message).

Title: Linux Kernel devfs Race Condition Lets Local Users Gain Root Level Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Linux kernel devfs implementation.  A race condition allows local users to obtain root level privileges.
The vulnerability is reportedly due to a race condition in devfs/base.c.  No further details were provided.

This flaw was reportedly discovered by Alexander Viro.
Impact': A local user could obtain root level privileges on the host.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  A workaround is to boot with the devfs=nomount option.

Title: Linux 2.4 Kernel Netfilter iptables Firewall Software May Fail to Properly Drop Some Packets
Description:
A security hole was reported in the Linux Netfilter iptables firewall software.  Remote users may be able to pass packets through the firewall in certain situations.
The flaw resides in the MAC module, which is designed to match packets based on their Ethernet MAC address.  It is reported that the MAC module does not correctly match very small packets.  If MAC matching/filtering is used, a remote user may be able to pass small packets through the firewall.
Impact': A remote user may be able to pass small packets through the firewall if MAC address matching is used in the rule set.
Solution:
A Netfilter patch has been developed:  [Editor's Note: The web page may have altered some line breaks.  A Base64 encoded version is available in the Source Message.]

--- linux-2.4.9/net/ipv4/netfilter/ipt_mac.c    Tue Oct  2 18:50:56 2001
+++ linux-2.4.9-ipt_mac-fix/net/ipv4/netfilter/ipt_mac.c        Tue Oct  2
19:32:20 2001
@@ -20,7 +20,7 @@

     /* Is mac pointer valid? */
     return (skb->mac.raw >= skb->head
-           && skb->mac.raw < skb->head + skb->len - ETH_HLEN
+           && (skb->mac.raw + ETH_HLEN) <= skb->data
            /* If so, compare... */
            && ((memcmp(skb->mac.ethernet->h_source, info->srcaddr, ETH_ALEN)
                == 0) ^ info->invert));

It is reported that a new and fixed version of iptables should be available in the near future, to be available at the Vendor URL.

Title: Linux TCP/IP Stack Vulnerable to a Certain Man-in-the-Middle Denial of Service Attack
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Linux 2.4.x kernel's TCP/IP stack that allows a man-in-the-middle to cause a denial of service condition.
It is reported that a man-in-the-middle attack that consists of just two TCP packets can cause a significant increase in network traffic and can cause the TCP connection to hang.

A remote user that can monitor network activity and collect the sequence and ACK numbers of an active TCP connection can then trigger an ACK loop by sending a spoofed TCP packet with the ACK and FIN flags enabled to both the source and destination hosts.  This will apparently cause the TCP/IP stacks of both the source and destination hosts to try to acknowledge that the peer side wants to close the connection and will therefore both send ACK packets.

As a result, a continious loop of ACK packet traffic between the source and destination hosts will occur.  This causes a significant increase in network traffic.  It also may cause the source and destination service to crash.
Impact': A remote user can cause a significant increase in network traffic and can cause the service using the TCP connection to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Locate Utility (/usr/bin/locate) on Slackware Linux May Allow Certain Local Users to Obtain Elevated Privileges, Incluing Root Level Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): part of findutils-4.1 and prior versions
Description:
A vulnerability was reported with the /usr/bin/locate utility that allows any local user with 'nobody' user privileges to potentially obtain elevated privileges, including root level privileges
It is reported that a local user with 'nobody' privileges (uid nobody) can modify the locate database and insert a trojan so that when another user (such as root) executes the locate function, the trojan code will be unknowingly executed, giving the local user access to the executing user's privileges.

It is reported that locate accepts old format databases. LOCATEDB_OLD_ESCAPE (char 30) is followed by an offset, stored in a signed integer, that indicates the number of characters to add to the current character pointer in the path. No sanity checking is performed on the input.  As a result, a local user can move the pointer back past the beginning of the string to the GOT address for exit() and can then add the address of some arbitrary shellcode.  This will cause the arbitrary shell code to be executed whenever a user runs 'locate'.

Demonstration exploit code is included in the Source Message (it is Base64 encoded).
Impact': A local user with 'nobody' user privileges can cause arbitrary code to be executed by other users that execute the 'locate' utility. The code will run with the privileges of the user calling the 'locate' utility, which could include a root user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (An Updated Patch is Provided) Re: Linux Kernel IP Masquerading (NAT) Module May Let Some Remote Users Send Packets Through the Firewall and Access the Protected Network
Version(s): Linux 2.0, Linux 2.2, and possibly other systems
Description: RAZOR reported that there is a vulnerability in the Linux 2.0 and 2.2 kernel in the IP masquerading module that performs network address translation (NAT). The security hole may allow some unauthorized connections to traverse the firewall in specific situations. It is reported that an additional protocol can be exploited by the NAT packet inspection vulnerability reported last year. The original report noted that, for the FTP protocol, certain external systems are temporarily allowed to initiate inbound connections in certain situations by using the firewall as a packet forwarder. It is reported that IRC DCC helper (the Linux 2.2 ip_masq_irc module, and modules shipped with some other operating systems and firewall software) can be exploited when a remote user on the protected network loads the following type of tag via an HTML web page or HTML-based e-mail: ("addr" is the internal host IP address represented as a decimal integer.) The remote attacker must then listen on tcp port 6667 on the specified remote host ("evil.host") and generate valid FTP protocol responses. The attacker will then receive information about the port number on the firewall that will be forwarded into the protected network.
Impact': A remote user can, in certain situations, pass unauthorized packets through the firewall.
Solution: This message contains an updated patch.  Do not use the patch in the original message.  See the Source Message for the patch.

Title: (Vendor Confirms and Clarifies) Re: Linux 2.4.x Kernel Creates World Writable Boot Files Letting Local Users Obtain Root Privileges When the System Reboots
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4.x kernel that may allow local users to obtain root level privileges by modifying certain boot files that improperly are created by the kernel bootup scripts with world writable permissions.
The modutils maintainer confirms the vulnerability and provides clarification on the vulnerability (see the Source Message).
Impact': A local user can cause arbitrary code to be executed at startup with root level privileges.
Solution: The vulnerability will be corrected in the next kernel release.

Title: Linux 2.4.x Kernel Creates World Writable Boot Files Letting Local Users Obtain Root Privileges When the System Reboots
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.4.x kernel that may allow local users to obtain root level privileges by modifying certain boot files that improperly are created by the kernel bootup scripts with world writable permissions.
It is reported that the 2.4.x kernels (possibly starting with 2.4.3) leave a umask of 0000 after loading.  As a result, any files created by the bootup scripts without the command `umask 022` will be world writeable.

In slackware, these files include /var/run/utmp, /var/run/gpm.pid, and /lib/modules/`uname -r`/modules.dep.

A local user can place object code in /lib/modules/`uname -r`/modules.dep that will be executed during the subsequent startup.  An example is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can cause arbitrary code to be executed at startup with root level privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The report suggests as a temporary workaround that users place umask 022 at the top of all startup scripts.

Title: Linux /proc Filesystem May Disclose Memory Contents Under Specific Circumstances to Local Users
Version(s): kernel 2.4.3 and prior, kernel 2.2.19 and prior
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Linux /proc filesystem, a virtual filesystem provided by the Linux kernel.  The security hole could allow local users to obtain data contained in memeory under specific circumstances.
It is reportedly possible, under certain circumstances, for a local user to read contents from /proc/$$/mem.  This can reportedly be achieved by close()ing standard input stream file descriptor fd 0, and re-open()ing it with /proc/<current_pid>/mem.  After re-opening it and altering the memory offset using lseek() to select the memory offset in the process you want to read from, the local user can read the memory contents (as text) from that memory position.

The /proc/<current_pid>/mem file handle remains open through the execve() call and the setuid process will have permission to read from it, as long as no other call to an exec() function has been made.

A demonstration exploit is included in the Source Message.  This exploit creates an example password processing application to demonstrate how passwords in memory can be obtain by exploiting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user could read arbitrary data contained in memory.  This could include previously-typed user input, such as passwords.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Red Hat's Mount Utility May Leave Sensitive Swap Files Containing Passwords on the System in World Readable Files
Description:
Red Hat released an advisory warning that the mount program contains a vulnerability that may allow local users to obtain sensitive data, including passwords, from the system.
Red Hat reports that if any swap files were created during installation or updates of Red Hat Linux 7.1, these swap files were improperly created as world-readable files.  As a result, every user on the system could read data in the swap file(s), which may include passwords.

The affected swap files are reported to be /mountpoint/SWAP and /mountpoint/SWAP-(numeral)

The vendor has released a fix.
Impact': A local user could read the swap files and obtain sensitive data, including passwords.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  Read the Source Message for details.  The following RPMs are available for Red Hat 7.1:

Title: Re: Red Hat May Use Less Secure File Permissions When Creating Some Files In Certain Situations
Description:
It is reported that users of Redhat may have their "umask" set insecurely while acting as root such that files created by the root user may have less secure permissions than intended.
A user adds the following notes:

Correction:  In the case of bash, if the '-' or '-l' option to 'su' is not
specified, then /etc/profile and ~/.bash_profile are not executed.  The
same holds true for ksh and sh in regards to /etc/profile and ~/.profile,
and /etc/profile and ~/.login for csh.

In the case of bash, /etc/bashrc and ~/.bashrc, and in the case of csh,
~/.cshrc will be processed, regardless.

In reference to the specific "problem" of su, the same holds true even if
one simply calls a shell without specifying that it be a login shell.  So
the problem isn't even specifically related to su -- it comes down to
simply setting the 'umask' value appropriately and having an understanding
of how such values are handled depending on your platform.
Impact': A local user that has switched to super user (using su without the -l option) and creates files may do so with a umask of "002", resulting in less secure file permissions being set for those files (e.g., rw-rw-r-- instead of rw-r--r--).  This may result in some files being more widely accessible than intended (i.e., to the group instead of just the user).
Solution:
The author makes a recommendation for a change in the /etc/profile configuration file.  See the source message for details.

Please note that, in a follow-up message (to be posted shortly), a user indicates that this is intended functionality and not a vulnerability.  See the Message History for more details (to be posted shortly).

This may result in some files being more widely accessible than intended (i.e., to the group instead of just the user).

Title: Red Hat May Use Less Secure File Permissions When Creating Some Files In Certain Situations
Description:
It is reported that users of Redhat may have their "umask" set insecurely while acting as root such that files created by the root user may have less secure permissions than intended.
The Redhat "useradd" script reportedly creates a group for the new user with the same name as the username by default.  When the user logs in, any shell that uses the /etc/profile settings will have the umask set to 002 as long as user's username and groupname match and their uid is greater than 14.  If the user then assumes root privileges by issuing the "su" command without specifying the -l option, the root account will inherit the umask of "002".  If the user (acting as root) then creates files, the resulting files may have less secure permissions than intended by the user.

Ordinarily, system users (e.g., root) have a umask of "022", as /etc/profile will set the umask to 022 for users loging in with a uid less than 14 (as root would be).  However, when a user executes "su", the lesser secure umask of "002" is assigned.

The relevant lines in /etc/profile are reported to be:

if [ `id -gn` = `id -un` -a `id -u` -gt 14 ]; then
        umask 002
else
        umask 022
fi
Impact': A local user that has switched to super user (using su without the -l option) and creates files may do so with a umask of "002", resulting in less secure file permissions being set for those files (e.g., rw-rw-r-- instead of rw-r--r--).  This may result in some files being more widely accessible than intended (i.e., to the group instead of just the user).
Solution:
The author makes a recommendation for a change in the /etc/profile configuration file.  See the source message for details.

Please note that, in a follow-up message (to be posted shortly), a user indicates that this is intended functionality and not a vulnerability.  See the Message History for more details (to be posted shortly).

Title: SuSE Linux's rctab Boot Utility Can Allow a Local User to Write Arbitrary Code to System Files
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): At least SuSE 6.1-7.0, maybe other systems using rctab.
Description:
The script /sbin/rctab is a tool for boot and run level managment for SuSE.  It is reported that there are race conditions that can allow a local user to overwrite any system file with arbitrary data, which can result in arbitrary code being executed, possibly with root privileges.
As reported, various race conditions in the init level editing script /sbin/rctab make it possible for a local user to overwrite any system file with arbitrary data. This may result in denial of service attack, local or even remote root compromise, if root runs the /sbin/rctab script.

The /sbin/rctab script doesn't check for links when writing the temporary rctmp file to /tmp/rctmpdir.$PID dir. Also, the resulting directory isn't chown'ed root. Because the process ID (PID) of the rctab script can be viewed by a local user, a local user can replace the temporary rctmp file with arbitrary content.
Impact': A local user could replace the rctmp file, thereby enabling/disabling any valid service listed in /sbin/init.d directory during reboot. A local user could force the rctab script to write the content of the rctmp file or some arbitrary code to any other system file.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.
